title: Dhammapada
subtitle: The Path of Dhamma
description: A collection of 423 verses from the Buddha's teachings, organized into 26 chapters covering the essential principles of Buddhist wisdom and practice.
translator: Various translators including Acharya Buddharakkhita, Thanissaro Bhikkhu, and others
source: Khuddaka Nikaya, Sutta Pitaka, Pali Tipitaka

verses.pali: Manopubbañgamā dhammā manoseṭṭhā manomayā; manasā ce paduṭṭhena bhāsati vā karoti vā tato naṃ dukkham anveti cakkaṃ va vahato padaṃ.
verses.english: Mind precedes all mental states. Mind is their chief; they are all mind-wrought. If with an impure mind a person speaks or acts, suffering follows him like the wheel that follows the foot of the ox.

verses.pali: Manopubbañgamā dhammā manoseṭṭhā manomayā; manasā ce pasannena bhāsati vā karoti vā tato naṃ sukham anveti chāyā va anapāyinī.
verses.english: Mind precedes all mental states. Mind is their chief; they are all mind-wrought. If with a pure mind a person speaks or acts, happiness follows him like his never-departing shadow.

verses.pali: "Akkocchi maṃ, avadhi maṃ, ajini maṃ, ahāsi me," ye ca taṃ upanayhanti, veraṃ tesaṃ na sammati.
verses.english: "He abused me, he struck me, he overpowered me, he robbed me"—those who harbor such thoughts do not still their hatred.

verses.pali: "Akkocchi maṃ, avadhi maṃ, ajini maṃ, ahāsi me," ye ca taṃ n'upanayhanti, veraṃ tes'ūpasammati.
verses.english: "He abused me, he struck me, he overpowered me, he robbed me"—those who do not harbor such thoughts still their hatred.

verses.pali: Na hi verena verāni sammant'īdha kudācanaṃ, averena ca sammanti: esa dhammo sanantano.
verses.english: Hatred is never appeased by hatred in this world; by non-hatred alone is hatred appeased. This is an eternal law.

verses.pali: Pare ca na vijānanti, mayam ettha yamāmase; ye ca tattha vijānanti, tato sammanti medhagā.
verses.english: There are those who do not realize that one day we all must die, but those who realize this settle their quarrels.

verses.pali: Subhānupassiṃ viharantaṃ indriyesu asaṃvutaṃ bhojanamhi cāmattaññuṃ kusītaṃ hīnavīriyaṃ, taṃ ve pasahati Māro vāto rukkhaṃ va dubbalaṃ.
verses.english: Just as a storm throws down a weak tree, so does Māra overpower one who lives for the pursuit of pleasures, who is uncontrolled in his senses, immoderate in eating, indolent and dissipated.

verses.pali: Asubhānupassiṃ viharantaṃ indriyesu susaṃvutaṃ bhojanamhi ca mattaññuṃ saddhaṃ āraddhavīriyaṃ, taṃ ve nappasahati Māro vāto selaṃ va pabbataṃ.
verses.english: Just as a storm cannot throw down a rocky mountain, so Māra can never overpower one who lives meditating on the impurities, who is controlled in his senses, moderate in eating, and filled with faith and earnest effort.

verses.pali: Anikkasāvo kāsāvaṃ yo vatthaṃ paridahissati apeto damasaccena, na so kāsāvam arahati.
verses.english: Whoever wears the monk's yellow robe while being depraved, devoid of self-control and truthfulness, he surely is not worthy of the yellow robe.

verses.pali: Yo ca vantakasāv'assa sīlesu susamāhito upeto damasaccena, sa ve kāsāvam arahati.
verses.english: But whoever is purged of depravity, well established in virtues, and filled with self-control and truthfulness, he indeed is worthy of the yellow robe.

verses.pali: Asāre sāramatino sāre cāsāradassino, te sāraṃ nādhigacchanti micchāsañkappagocarā.
verses.english: Those who mistake the unessential to be essential and the essential to be unessential, dwelling in wrong thoughts, never arrive at the essential.

verses.pali: Sārañ ca sārato ñatvā asārañ ca asārato, te sāram adhigacchanti sammāsañkappagocarā.
verses.english: Those who know the essential to be essential and the unessential to be unessential, dwelling in right thoughts, arrive at the essential.

verses.pali: Yathā agāraṃ ducchannaṃ vuṭṭhi samativijjhati, evaṃ abhāvitaṃ cittaṃ rāgo samativijjhati.
verses.english: Just as the rain breaks through an ill-thatched house, even so passion penetrates an undeveloped mind.

verses.pali: Yathā agāraṃ succhannaṃ vuṭṭhi na samativijjhati, evaṃ subhāvitaṃ cittaṃ rāgo na samativijjhati.
verses.english: Just as the rain does not break through a well-thatched house, even so passion never penetrates a well-developed mind.

verses.pali: Idha socati pecca socati, pāpakārī ubhayattha socati; so socati so vihaññati, disvā kammakiliṭṭham attano.
verses.english: The evil-doer grieves here, he grieves hereafter; he grieves in both worlds. He laments and is afflicted, recollecting his own impure deeds.

verses.pali: Idha modati pecca modati, katapuñño ubhayattha modati; so modati so pamodati, disvā kammavisuddhim attano.
verses.english: The doer of good rejoices here, he rejoices hereafter; he rejoices in both worlds. He rejoices and exults, recollecting his own pure deeds.

verses.pali: Idha tappati pecca tappati, pāpakārī ubhayattha tappati; pāpaṃ me katan ti tappati, bhiyyo tappati duggatim gato.
verses.english: The evil-doer suffers here, he suffers hereafter; he suffers in both worlds. The thought, "Evil have I done," torments him, and he suffers even more when gone to realms of woe.

verses.pali: Idha nandati pecca nandati, katapuñño ubhayattha nandati; puññaṃ me katan ti nandati, bhiyyo nandati suggatim gato.
verses.english: The doer of good delights here, he delights hereafter; he delights in both worlds. The thought, "Good have I done," delights him, and he delights even more when gone to realms of bliss.

verses.pali: Bahum pi ce sahitaṃ bhāsamāno na takkaro hoti naro pamatto gopo va gāvo gaṇayaṃ paresaṃ na bhāgavā sāmaññassa hoti.
verses.english: Although he recites many sacred texts, if he does not act accordingly, that heedless man is like a cowherd who only counts the cattle of others—he does not partake of the blessings of a holy life.

verses.pali: Appam pi ce sahitaṃ bhāsamāno dhammassa hoti anudhammacārī rāgañ ca dosañ ca pahāya mohaṃ sammappajāno suvimuttacitto anupādiyāno idha vā huraṃ vā, sa bhāgavā sāmaññassa hoti.
verses.english: Although he recites few sacred texts, if he puts the Dhamma into practice, forsaking lust, hatred, and delusion, with true wisdom and emancipated mind, clinging to nothing in this or any other world—he, indeed, partakes of the blessings of a holy life.

verses.pali: Appamādo amatapadaṃ, pamādo maccuno padaṃ; appamattā na mīyanti, ye pamattā yathā matā.
verses.english: Heedfulness is the path to the Deathless, heedlessness is the path to death. The heedful do not die, the heedless are already dead.

verses.pali: Etaṃ visesato ñatvā appamādamhi paṇḍitā, appamāde pamodanti ariyānaṃ gocare ratā.
verses.english: Clearly understanding this excellence of heedfulness, the wise exult therein and enjoy the resort of the noble ones.

verses.pali: Te jhāyino sātatikā niccaṃ daḷhaparakkamā, phusanti dhīrā nibbānaṃ yogakkhemaṃ anuttaraṃ.
verses.english: The wise ones, ever meditative and steadfastly persevering, experience Nibbāna, the incomparable freedom from bondage.

verses.pali: Uṭṭhānavato satimato sucikammassa nisammakārino saññatassa ca dhammajīvino appamattassa yaso' bhivaḍḍhati.
verses.english: Ever grows the glory of one who is energetic, mindful, and pure in conduct, discerning and self-controlled, righteous and heedful.

verses.pali: Uṭṭhānen'appamādena saññamena damena ca dīpaṃ kayirātha medhāvī yaṃ ogho nābhikīrati.
verses.english: By effort and heedfulness, discipline and self-mastery, let the wise one make for himself an island which no flood can overwhelm.

verses.pali: Pamādam anuyuñjanti bālā dummedhino janā, appamādañ ca medhāvī dhanaṃ seṭṭhaṃ va rakkhati.
verses.english: The foolish and ignorant indulge in heedlessness, but the wise one guards heedfulness as his best treasure.

verses.pali: Mā pamādam anuyuñjetha, mā kāmaratisanthavaṃ; appamatto hi jhāyanto pappoti vipulaṃ sukhaṃ.
verses.english: Do not give way to heedlessness; do not indulge in sensual pleasures. Only the heedful and meditative attain great happiness.

verses.pali: Pamādaṃ appamādena yadā nudati paṇḍito, paññāpāsādam āruyha asoko sokiniṃ pajaṃ, pabbataṭṭho va bhummaṭṭhe, dhīro bāle avekkhati.
verses.english: Just as one upon the summit of a mountain beholds the groundlings, even so when the wise man casts away heedlessness by heedfulness and ascends the high tower of wisdom, this sorrowless sage beholds the sorrowing and foolish multitude.

verses.pali: Appamatto pamattesu suttesu bahujāgaro abalassaṃ va sīghasso hitvā yāti sumedhaso.
verses.english: Heedful among the heedless, wide awake among the sleepy, the wise man advances like a swift horse leaving behind a weak nag.

verses.pali: Appamādena Maghavā devānaṃ seṭṭhataṃ gato; appamādaṃ pasaṃsanti pamādo garahito sadā.
verses.english: By heedfulness did Indra become the overlord of the gods. Heedfulness is ever praised, and heedlessness ever despised.

verses.pali: Appamādarato bhikkhu pamāde bhayadassivā saññojanaṃ aṇuṃ thūlaṃ ḍahaṃ aggī va gacchati.
verses.english: The monk who delights in heedfulness and looks with fear at heedlessness advances like fire, burning all fetters subtle and coarse.

verses.pali: Appamādarato bhikkhu pamāde bhayadassivā abhabbo parihānāya, nibbānass'eva santike.
verses.english: The monk who delights in heedfulness and looks with fear at heedlessness will not fall. He is close to Nibbāna.

verses.pali: Phandanaṃ capalaṃ cittaṃ durakkhaṃ dunnivārayaṃ ujuṃ karoti medhāvī usukāro va tejanaṃ.
verses.english: Just as an arrow-maker straightens an arrow shaft, even so the discerning person straightens his mind—so fickle and unsteady, so difficult to guard and control.

verses.pali: Vārijo va thale khitto okamokata ubbhato, pariphandatidaṃ cittaṃ Māradheyyaṃ pahātave.
verses.english: As a fish when pulled out of water and cast on land throbs and quivers, even so is this mind agitated. Hence one should leave the realm of Māra.

verses.pali: Dunniggahassa lahuno yatthakāmanipātino cittassa damatho sādhu: cittaṃ dantaṃ sukhāvahaṃ.
verses.english: Wonderful, indeed, it is to subdue the mind, so difficult to subdue, ever swift, and wandering wherever it desires. A tamed mind brings happiness.

verses.pali: Sududdasaṃ sunipuṇaṃ yatthakāmanipātinaṃ cittaṃ rakkhetha medhāvī: cittaṃ guttaṃ sukhāvahaṃ.
verses.english: Let the discerning person guard his mind, so difficult to detect and extremely subtle, wandering wherever it desires. A guarded mind brings happiness.

verses.pali: Dūraṅgamaṃ ekacaraṃ asarīraṃ guhāsayaṃ ye cittaṃ saññamessanti mokkhanti Mārabandhanā.
verses.english: Dwelling in the cave (of the heart), without form, the mind wanders far and moves alone. Those who subdue this mind are liberated from the bonds of Māra.

verses.pali: Anavaṭṭhitacittassa saddhammaṃ avijānato pariplavapasādassa paññā na paripūrati.
verses.english: Wisdom is not perfected in one whose mind is not steadfast, who knows not the Good Teaching, and whose faith wavers.

verses.pali: Anavassutacittassa ananvāhatacetaso puññapāpapahīnassa natthi jāgarato bhayaṃ.
verses.english: There is no fear for an Awakened One, whose mind is not sodden (by lust) nor afflicted (by hate), and who has gone beyond both merit and demerit.

verses.pali: Kumbhūpamaṃ kāyam imaṃ viditvā, nagarūpamaṃ cittam idaṃ ṭhapetvā, yodhetha Māraṃ paññāvudhena, jitañ ca rakkhe anivesano siyā.
verses.english: Realizing that this body is as fragile as a clay pot, and fortifying this mind like a well-fortified city, fight out Māra with the sword of wisdom. Then, guarding the conquest, remain unattached.

verses.pali: Aciraṃ vatayaṃ kāyo paṭhaviṃ adhisessati chuddho apetaviññāno niratthaṃ va kalingaraṃ.
verses.english: Before long, alas, this body will lie upon the earth, cast away and lifeless, like a useless log.

verses.pali: Diso disaṃ yaṃ taṃ kayirā verī vā pana verinaṃ, micchāpaṇihitaṃ cittaṃ pāpiyo naṃ tato kare.
verses.english: Whatever harm an enemy may do to an enemy, or a hater to a hater, an ill-directed mind inflicts on oneself greater harm.

verses.pali: Na taṃ mātā pitā kayirā aññe vāpi ca ñātakā, sammāpaṇihitaṃ cittaṃ seyyaso naṃ tato kare.
verses.english: Neither mother, father, nor any other relative can do one greater good than one's own well-directed mind.

verses.pali: Ko imaṃ paṭhaviṃ vijessati Yamalokañ ca imaṃ sadevakaṃ? ko dhammapadaṃ sudesitaṃ kusalo puppham iva pacessati?
verses.english: Who shall overcome this earth, the world of misery, and this sphere of humans and gods? Who shall bring to perfection the well-taught path of wisdom as an expert garland-maker would his floral design?

verses.pali: Sekho paṭhaviṃ vijessati Yamalokañ ca imaṃ sadevakaṃ, sekho dhammapadaṃ sudesitaṃ kusalo puppham iva pacessati.
verses.english: A striver-on-the-path shall overcome this earth, the world of misery, and this sphere of humans and gods. The striver-on-the-path shall bring to perfection the well-taught path of wisdom, as an expert garland-maker would his floral design.

verses.pali: Pheṇūpamaṃ kāyam imaṃ viditvā marīcidhammaṃ abhisambudhāno chetvāna Mārassa papupphakāni adassanaṃ Maccurājassa gacche.
verses.english: Realizing that this body is like froth, penetrating its mirage-like nature, and plucking out Māra's flower-tipped arrows (of sensuality), go beyond sight of the King of Death!

verses.pali: Pupphāni heva pacinantaṃ byāsattamanasaṃ naraṃ suttaṃ gāmaṃ mahogho va maccu ādāya gacchati.
verses.english: As a mighty flood sweeps away the sleeping village, so Death carries away the person of grasping mind who only collects the flowers (of pleasure).

verses.pali: Pupphāni heva pacinantaṃ byāsattamanasaṃ naraṃ atittaṃ yeva kāmesu antako kurute vasaṃ.
verses.english: The Destroyer brings under his sway the person of grasping mind who, insatiate in sense desires, only collects the flowers (of pleasure).

verses.pali: Yathāpi bhamaro pupphaṃ vaṇṇagandhaṃ aheṭhayaṃ paleti rasam ādāya evaṃ gāme munī care.
verses.english: As a bee gathers honey from the flower without injuring its colour or fragrance, even so the sage should go on his alms round in the village.

verses.pali: Na paresaṃ vilomāni na paresaṃ katākataṃ attano va avekkheyya katāni akatāni ca.
verses.english: Let none find fault with others; let none see the omissions and commissions of others. But let one see one's own acts, done and undone.

verses.pali: Yathāpi ruciraṃ pupphaṃ vaṇṇavantaṃ agandhakaṃ, evaṃ subhāsitā vācā aphalā hoti akubbato.
verses.english: Like a beautiful flower full of colour but without fragrance, even so, fruitless are the fair words of one who does not practice them.

verses.pali: Yathāpi ruciraṃ pupphaṃ vaṇṇavantaṃ sagandhakaṃ, evaṃ subhāsitā vācā saphalā hoti sakubbato.
verses.english: Like a beautiful flower full of colour and also fragrant, even so, fruitful are the fair words of one who practices them.

verses.pali: Yathāpi puppharāsimhā kayirā mālāguṇe bahū, evaṃ jātena maccena kattabbaṃ kusalaṃ bahuṃ.
verses.english: As from a great heap of flowers many garlands can be made, even so should many good deeds be done by one born a mortal.

verses.pali: Na pupphagandho paṭivātam eti, na candanaṃ tagaramallikā vā, satañ ca gandho paṭivātam eti; sabbā disā sappuriso pavāti.
verses.english: Not the sweet smell of flowers, not even the fragrance of sandal, tagara, or jasmine goes against the wind. But the fragrance of the virtuous goes against the wind. The virtuous person pervades all directions with the fragrance of virtue.

verses.pali: Candanaṃ tagaraṃ vāpi uppalaṃ atha vassikī, etesaṃ gandhajātānaṃ sīlagandho anuttaro.
verses.english: Of all the fragrances—sandal, tagara, blue lotus, and jasmine—the fragrance of virtue is by far the sweetest.

verses.pali: Appamatto ayaṃ gandho yāyaṃ tagaracandanī, yo ca sīlavataṃ gandho vāti devesu uttamo.
verses.english: Faint is the fragrance of tagara and sandal, but the fragrance of the virtuous is excellent, wafting even among the gods.

verses.pali: Tesaṃ sampannasīlānaṃ appamādavihārinaṃ sammadaññā vimuttānaṃ Māro maggaṃ na vindati.
verses.english: Māra never finds the path of the truly virtuous, who abide in vigilance and are freed by perfect knowledge.

verses.pali: Yathā saṅkāradhānasmiṃ ujjhitasmiṃ mahāpathe padumaṃ tattha jāyetha sucigandhaṃ manoramaṃ.
verses.english: As upon a heap of rubbish in the roadside ditch blooms a lotus, fragrant and pleasing,

verses.pali: Evaṃ saṅkārabhūtesu andhabhūte puthujjane atirocati paññāya Sammāsambuddhasāvako.
verses.english: even so, on the rubbish heap of blind worldlings the disciple of the Supremely Enlightened One shines resplendent in wisdom.

verses.pali: Dīghā jāgarato ratti, dīghaṃ santassa yojanaṃ, dīgho bālānaṃ saṃsāro saddhammaṃ avijānataṃ.
verses.english: Long is the night to the wakeful; long is the league to the weary. Long is worldly existence to fools who know not the sublime truth.

verses.pali: Carañ ce nādhigaccheyya seyyaṃ sadisamattano, ekacariyaṃ daḷhaṃ kayirā, natthi bāle sahāyatā.
verses.english: If, as the disciple fares along, he meets no companion who is better or equal, let him firmly pursue the solitary path; there is no fellowship with the fool.

verses.pali: "Puttā m'atthi, dhanaṃ m'atthi," iti bālo vihaññati. Attā hi attano natthi, kuto puttā, kuto dhanaṃ?
verses.english: "Sons are mine, wealth is mine"—with such thoughts a fool is tormented. He himself is not his own; how much less sons and wealth?

verses.pali: Yo bālo maññati bālyaṃ paṇḍito so tato hoti, bālo ca paṇḍitamānī sa ve bālo ti vuccati.
verses.english: The fool who knows his foolishness is wise at least to that extent, but a fool who thinks himself wise is called a fool indeed.

verses.pali: Yāvajīvam pi ce bālo paṇḍitaṃ payirupāsati, na so dhammaṃ vijānāti dabbī rasaṃ yathā.
verses.english: Even though a fool associates with a wise man all his life, he will perceive the truth as little as a spoon perceives the taste of soup.

verses.pali: Muhuttam api ce viññū paṇḍitaṃ payirupāsati, khippaṃ dhammaṃ vijānāti jivhā rasaṃ yathā.
verses.english: Even though a wise man associates with a wise man only a moment, he will immediately perceive the truth, just as the tongue perceives the taste of soup.

verses.pali: Caranti bālā dummedhā amitteneva attanā, karontā pāpakaṃ kammaṃ yaṃ hoti kaṭukapphalaṃ.
verses.english: Fools of little understanding have themselves for their greatest enemies, for they do evil deeds which must bear bitter fruits.

verses.pali: Na taṃ kammaṃ kataṃ sādhu yaṃ katvā anutappati, yassa assumukho rodaṃ vipākaṃ paṭisevati.
verses.english: That deed is not well done of which a man must repent, and the reward of which he receives crying and with a tearful face.

verses.pali: Tañ ca kammaṃ kataṃ sādhu yaṃ katvā nānutappati, yassa patīto sumano vipākaṃ paṭisevati.
verses.english: That deed is well done of which a man does not repent, and the reward of which he receives gladly and cheerfully.

verses.pali: Madhuvā maññati bālo yāva pāpaṃ na paccati, yadā ca paccati pāpaṃ atha bālo dukkhaṃ nigacchati.
verses.english: As long as the evil deed does not bear fruit, the fool thinks it is like honey; but when it ripens, then the fool suffers grief.

verses.pali: Māse māse kusaggena bālo bhuñjeyya bhojanaṃ, na so saṅkhātadhammānaṃ kalaṃ agghati soḷasiṃ.
verses.english: Month after month the fool may eat his food with the tip of a blade of grass, but he is not worth the sixteenth part of those who have comprehended the truth.

verses.pali: Na hi pāpaṃ kataṃ kammaṃ sajju khīraṃ va muccati, ḍahantaṃ bālamanveti bhasmacchanno va pāvako.
verses.english: An evil deed, like newly-drawn milk, does not turn sour immediately; smouldering, it follows the fool like fire covered by ashes.

verses.pali: Yāvad eva anatthāya ñattaṃ bālassa jāyati, hanti bālassa sukkaṃsaṃ muddham assa vipātayaṃ.
verses.english: To his own ruin the fool gains knowledge and fame, for they destroy his bright nature and cleave his head.

verses.pali: Asantaṃ bhāvanam iccheyya purekkhārañ ca bhikkhusu, āvāsesu ca issariyaṃ pūjā parakulesu ca.
verses.english: The fool seeks undeserved reputation, precedence among monks, authority in the monasteries, and honour among other families.

verses.pali: "Mayā idaṃ kataṃ" iti maññantu gihī pabbajitā ca, "Mayā eva ativattiṃsu kiccākiccesu kismici," iti bālassa saṅkappo, icchā māno ca vaḍḍhati.
verses.english: "Let both laymen and monks think that this is done by me; let them be subject to me in this and that matter"—such is the thought of the fool; his desire and pride increase.

verses.pali: Aññā hi lābhūpanisā aññā nibbānagāminī, evam etaṃ abhiññāya bhikkhu Buddhasāvako sakkāraṃ nābhinandeyya vivekam anubrūhaye.
verses.english: One is the road that leads to wealth, another the road that leads to Nibbāna; if the monk, the disciple of the Buddha, has learned this, he will not yearn for honour but will strive for solitude.

verses.pali: Nidhīnaṃ va pavattāraṃ yaṃ passe vajjadassinaṃ, niggayhavādiṃ medhāviṃ tādisaṃ paṇḍitaṃ bhaje, tādisaṃ bhajamānassa seyyo hoti na pāpiyo.
verses.english: Should one find a man who points out faults and reproves, let him follow such a wise and sagacious person as one would a guide to hidden treasure. It is always better, and never worse, to cultivate such an association.

verses.pali: Ovadeyyānusāseyya asabbhā ca nivāraye, satañ hi so piyo hoti asataṃ hoti dubbhiyo.
verses.english: Let him admonish, instruct, and shield one from wrong; he is dear to the good and detestable to the evil.

verses.pali: Na bhaje pāpake mitte na bhaje purisādhame, bhajetha mitte kalyāṇe bhajetha purisuttame.
verses.english: Do not associate with evil companions; do not seek the fellowship of the vile. Associate with the good friends; seek the fellowship of noble men.

verses.pali: Dhammapīti sukhaṃ seti vippasannena cetasā, ariyappavedite dhamme sadā ramati paṇḍito.
verses.english: He who drinks deeply of the Dhamma lives happily with a tranquil mind. The wise man ever delights in the Dhamma made known by the Noble One (the Buddha).

verses.pali: Udakaṃ hi nayanti nettikā, usukārā namayanti tejanaṃ, dāruṃ namayanti tacchakā, attānaṃ damayanti paṇḍitā.
verses.english: Irrigators channel waters; fletchers straighten arrows; carpenters bend wood; the wise master themselves.

verses.pali: Selo yathā ekaghano vātena na samīrati, evaṃ nindāpasaṃsāsu na samiñjanti paṇḍitā.
verses.english: As a solid rock is unshaken by the wind, even so the wise are unperturbed by praise or blame.

verses.pali: Yathāpi rahado gambhīro vippasanno anāvilo, evaṃ dhammāni sutvāna vippasīdanti paṇḍitā.
verses.english: On hearing the Teachings, the wise become perfectly purified, like a lake deep, clear, and still.

verses.pali: Sabbattha ve sappurisā cajanti, na kāmakāmā lapayanti santo, sukhena phuṭṭhā atha vā dukhena na uccāvacaṃ paṇḍitā dassayanti.
verses.english: Good people walk on regardless of what happens to them. Good people do not babble, yearning for pleasure. The wise show no elation or depression when touched by happiness or sorrow.

verses.pali: Na attahetu na parassa hetu na puttam icche na dhanaṃ na raṭṭhaṃ, na iccheyya adhammena samiddhim attano, sa sīlavā paññavā dhammiko siyā.
verses.english: Neither for the sake of oneself nor for the sake of another (does a wise person do any wrong); he should not desire son, wealth, or kingdom (by doing wrong). By unjust means he should not seek his own success. Then (only) is he virtuous, wise, and righteous.

verses.pali: Appakā te manussesu ye janā pāragāmino, athāyaṃ itarā pajā tīram evānudhāvati.
verses.english: Few among men are those who cross to the further shore. The others merely run up and down the hither bank.

verses.pali: Ye ca kho sammadakkhāte dhamme dhammānuvattino, te janā pāram essanti Maccudheyyaṃ suduttaraṃ.
verses.english: But those who act according to the perfectly taught Dhamma will cross the realm of Death, so difficult to cross.

verses.pali: Kaṇhaṃ dhammaṃ vippahāya sukkaṃ bhāvetha paṇḍito, okā anokam āgamma viveke yattha dūramaṃ.
verses.english: Abandoning the dark way, let the wise person cultivate the bright path. Having gone from home to homelessness, let him yearn for that joy in detachment, so difficult to enjoy.

verses.pali: Tatrābhiratim iccheyya hitvā kāme akiñcano, pariyodapeyya attānaṃ cittaklesehi paṇḍito.
verses.english: Giving up sensual pleasures, with no attachment, the wise person should cleanse himself of defilements of the mind.

verses.pali: Yesaṃ sambodhiyaṅgesu sammā cittaṃ subhāvitaṃ, ādānapaṭinissagge anupādāya ye ratā, khīṇāsavā jutimanto te loke parinibbutā.
verses.english: Those whose minds have reached full excellence in the factors of enlightenment, who having renounced acquisitiveness, rejoice in not clinging to things—rid of cankers, glowing with wisdom, they have attained Nibbāna in this very life.

verses.pali: Gataddhino visokassa vippamuttassa sabbadhi, sabbaganthappahīnassa pariḷāho na vijjati.
verses.english: There is no suffering for him who has completed the journey, who is sorrowless and wholly set free, and has broken all ties.

verses.pali: Uyyuñjanti satīmanto na nikete ramanti te, haṃsā va pallalaṃ hitvā okam okaṃ jahanti te.
verses.english: The mindful ones exert themselves. They are not attached to any home; like swans that abandon the lake, they leave home after home behind.

verses.pali: Yesaṃ sannicayo natthi ye pariññātabhojanā, suññato animitto ca vimokkho yesa gocaro, ākāse va sakuntānaṃ gati tesaṃ durannayā.
verses.english: Those who do not accumulate and are wise regarding food, whose object is the Void, the Unconditioned Freedom—their track cannot be traced, like that of birds in the air.

verses.pali: Yassāsavā parikkhīṇā āhāre ca anissito, suññato animitto ca vimokkho yassa gocaro, ākāse va sakuntānaṃ padaṃ tassa durannayaṃ.
verses.english: He whose cankers are destroyed and who is not attached to food, whose object is the Void, the Unconditioned Freedom—his path cannot be traced, like that of birds in the air.

verses.pali: Yassindriyāni samathaṅgatāni assā yathā sārathināsudhantā, pahīnamānassa anāsavassa devāpi tassa pihayanti tādino.
verses.english: Even the gods hold dear the wise one, whose senses are subdued like horses well trained by a charioteer, whose pride is destroyed and who is free from the cankers.

verses.pali: Paṭhavisamoṃ no virujjhati indakhīlo va tādi tāl, rahado va apetakaddamo saṃsārā na bhavanti tādino.
verses.english: Like the earth, a balanced and well-disciplined person is not shaken by praise or blame. He is like a serene lake, clear and undisturbed; the rounds of rebirth do not befall such a one.

verses.pali: Santaṃ tassa manaṃ hoti santā vācā ca kamma ca, sammadaññā vimuttassa upasantassa tādino.
verses.english: Calm is his thought, calm his speech, and calm his deed, who, truly knowing, is wholly freed, perfectly tranquil and wise.

verses.pali: Assaddho akataññū ca sandhicchedo ca yo naro, hatāvakāso vantāso sa ve uttamaporiso.
verses.english: The man who is without blind faith, who knows the Uncreated, who has severed all ties, destroyed all causes (for karma, good and evil), and thrown out all desires—he, truly, is the most excellent of men.

verses.pali: Gāme vā yadi vāraññe ninne vā yadi vā thale, yattha arahanto viharanti taṃ bhūmiṃ rāmaṇeyyakaṃ.
verses.english: Inspiring, indeed, is that place where Arahants dwell, be it a village or a forest, a vale or a hill.

verses.pali: Ramaṇīyāni araññāni yattha na ramatī jano, vītarāgā ramissanti na te kāmagavesino.
verses.english: Inspiring are the forests in which worldlings find no pleasure. There the passionless will rejoice, for they seek no sensual pleasures.

verses.pali: Sahassamapi ce vācā anatthapadasaṃhitā, ekaṃ atthapadaṃ seyyo yaṃ sutvā upasammati.
verses.english: Better than a thousand useless words is one useful word, hearing which one attains peace.

verses.pali: Sahassamapi ce gāthā anatthapadasaṃhitā, ekaṃ gāthāpadaṃ seyyo yaṃ sutvā upasammati.
verses.english: Better than a thousand useless verses is one useful verse, hearing which one attains peace.

verses.pali: Yo ca gāthāsataṃ bhāse anatthapadasaṃhitaṃ, ekaṃ dhammapadaṃ seyyo yaṃ sutvā upasammati.
verses.english: Better than reciting a hundred meaningless verses is the reciting of one verse of Dhamma, hearing which one attains peace.

verses.pali: Yo sahassaṃ sahassena saṅgāme mānuse jine, ekañ ca jeyyamattānaṃ sa ve saṅgāmajuttamo.
verses.english: Though one may conquer a thousand times a thousand men in battle, yet he indeed is the noblest victor who conquers himself.

verses.pali: Attā have jitaṃ seyyo yā cāyaṃ itarā pajā, attadantassa posassa niccaṃ saññatacārino.
verses.english: Self-conquest is far better than the conquest of others. Not even a god, an angel, Māra or Brahmā could turn into defeat the victory of a person who is self-subdued and ever restrained in conduct.

verses.pali: Neva devo na gandhabbo na Māro saha Brahmunā, jitaṃ apajitaṃ kayirā tathārūpassa jantuno.
verses.english: Not even a god, an angel, Māra or Brahmā could turn into defeat the victory of such a person who is self-subdued and ever restrained in conduct.

verses.pali: Māse māse sahassena yo yajetha sataṃ samaṃ, ekañ ca bhāvitattānaṃ muhuttamapi pūjaye, sā yeva pūjanā seyyo yañ ce vassasataṃ hutaṃ.
verses.english: Month after month, for a hundred years, one might make offerings of a thousand (coins), but if only for a moment one honours a self-developed person, that honour is indeed better than a century of sacrifice.

verses.pali: Yo ca vassasataṃ jantu aggiṃ paricare vane, ekañ ca bhāvitattānaṃ muhuttamapi pūjaye, sā yeva pūjanā seyyo yañ ce vassasataṃ hutaṃ.
verses.english: Though for a hundred years a person worships fire in the forest, yet if only for a moment he honours a self-developed person, that honour is indeed better than a century of fire-worship.

verses.pali: Yaṃ kiñci yiṭṭhaṃ va hutaṃ vā loke saṃvaccharaṃ yajetha puññapekkho, sabbampi taṃ na catubhāgameti abhivādanā ujjugatesu.
verses.english: Whatever gifts and oblations one seeking merit might offer in this world for a whole year, all that is not worth one fourth of the merit gained by revering the Upright Ones.

verses.pali: Abhivādanasīlissa niccaṃ vuḍḍhāpacāyino, cattāro dhammā vaḍḍhanti āyu vaṇṇo sukhaṃ balaṃ.
verses.english: For one who is in the habit of constantly honouring and respecting the elders, four benefits increase: long life, beauty, happiness, and strength.

verses.pali: Yo ca vassasataṃ jīve dussīlo asamāhito, ekāhaṃ jīvitaṃ seyyo sīlavantassa jhāyino.
verses.english: Better it is to live one day virtuous and meditative than to live a hundred years immoral and uncontrolled.

verses.pali: Yo ca vassasataṃ jīve duppañño asamāhito, ekāhaṃ jīvitaṃ seyyo paññavantassa jhāyino.
verses.english: Better it is to live one day wise and meditative than to live a hundred years ignorant and uncontrolled.

verses.pali: Yo ca vassasataṃ jīve kusīto hīnavīriyo, ekāhaṃ jīvitaṃ seyyo vīriyamārabhato daḷhaṃ.
verses.english: Better it is to live one day strenuous and resolute than to live a hundred years sluggish and dissipated.

verses.pali: Yo ca vassasataṃ jīve apassaṃ udayabbayaṃ, ekāhaṃ jīvitaṃ seyyo passato udayabbayaṃ.
verses.english: Better it is to live one day seeing the rise and fall of things than to live a hundred years without ever seeing the rise and fall of things.

verses.pali: Yo ca vassasataṃ jīve apassaṃ amataṃ padaṃ, ekāhaṃ jīvitaṃ seyyo passato amataṃ padaṃ.
verses.english: Better it is to live one day seeing the Deathless State than to live a hundred years without ever seeing the Deathless State.

verses.pali: Yo ca vassasataṃ jīve apassaṃ dhammamuttamaṃ, ekāhaṃ jīvitaṃ seyyo passato dhammamuttamaṃ.
verses.english: Better it is to live one day seeing the Supreme Truth than to live a hundred years without ever seeing the Supreme Truth.

verses.pali: Abhittharetha kalyāṇe pāpā cittaṃ nivāraye, dandhañ hi karoto puññaṃ pāpasmiṃ ramatī mano.
verses.english: Hasten to do good; restrain your mind from evil. He who is slow in doing good, his mind delights in evil.

verses.pali: Pāpañ ce puriso kayirā na naṃ kayirā punappunaṃ, na tamhi chandaṃ kayirātha dukkho pāpassa uccayo.
verses.english: Should a person commit evil, let him not do it again and again. Let him not find pleasure therein, for painful is the accumulation of evil.

verses.pali: Puññañ ce puriso kayirā kayirāth'enaṃ punappunaṃ, tamhi chandaṃ kayirātha sukho puññassa uccayo.
verses.english: Should a person do good, let him do it again and again. Let him find pleasure therein, for blissful is the accumulation of good.

verses.pali: Pāpo pi passati bhadraṃ yāva pāpaṃ na paccati, yadā ca paccati pāpaṃ atha pāpo pāpāni passati.
verses.english: It may be well with the evil-doer as long as the evil ripens not. But when it does ripen, then the evil-doer sees (the painful results of) evil deeds.

verses.pali: Bhadro pi passati pāpaṃ yāva bhadraṃ na paccati, yadā ca paccati bhadraṃ atha bhadro bhadrāni passati.
verses.english: It may be ill with the doer of good as long as the good ripens not. But when it does ripen, then the doer of good sees (the pleasant results of) good deeds.

verses.pali: Māvamaññetha pāpassa na maṃ taṃ āgamissatī ti, udabindunipātena udakumbho pi pūrati, dhīro pūrati pāpassa thokathokam pi ācinaṃ.
verses.english: Think not lightly of evil, saying, "It will not come to me." Drop by drop is the water pot filled. Likewise, the fool, gathering it little by little, fills himself with evil.

verses.pali: Māvamaññetha puññassa na maṃ taṃ āgamissatī ti, udabindunipātena udakumbho pi pūrati, dhīro pūrati puññassa thokathokam pi ācinaṃ.
verses.english: Think not lightly of good, saying, "It will not come to me." Drop by drop is the water pot filled. Likewise, the wise man, gathering it little by little, fills himself with good.

verses.pali: Vāṇijo va bhayaṃ maggaṃ appasattho mahaddhano, visaṃ jīvitukāmo va pāpāni parivajjaye.
verses.english: Just as a trader with a small escort and great wealth shuns a perilous route, or just as one desiring to live avoids poison, even so should one shun evil deeds.

verses.pali: Pāṇimhi ce vaṇo nāssa hareyya pāṇinā visaṃ, nābbaṇaṃ visam anveti natthi pāpaṃ akubbato.
verses.english: If on the hand there is no wound, one may carry poison in it. Poison does not affect one who is free from wounds. For him who does no evil, there is no ill.

verses.pali: Yo appaduṭṭhassa narassa dussati suddhassa posassa anaṅgaṇassa, tam eva bālaṃ pacceti pāpaṃ sukhumo rajo paṭivātaṃ va khitto.
verses.english: Like fine dust thrown against the wind, evil falls back upon that fool who offends an inoffensive, pure, and guiltless man.

verses.pali: Gabbham eke uppajjanti nirayaṃ pāpakammino, saggaṃ sugatino yanti parinibbanti anāsavā.
verses.english: Some are born in the womb; the wicked are born in hell; the righteous go to heaven; the stainless pass into Nibbāna.

verses.pali: Na antalikkhe na samuddamajjhe na pabbatānaṃ vivaraṃ pavissa, na vijjatī so jagatippadeso yattha ṭhito mucceyya pāpakammā.
verses.english: Neither in the sky nor in mid-ocean, nor by entering into mountain clefts, nowhere in the world is there a place where one may escape from the results of evil deeds.

verses.pali: Na antalikkhe na samuddamajjhe na pabbatānaṃ vivaraṃ pavissa, na vijjatī so jagatippadeso yattha ṭhitaṃ nappasaheyya maccu.
verses.english: Neither in the sky nor in mid-ocean, nor by entering into mountain clefts, nowhere in the world is there a place where one may escape from death.

verses.pali: Sabbe tasanti daṇḍassa sabbe bhāyanti maccuno, attānaṃ upanamaṃ katvā na haneyya na ghātaye.
verses.english: All tremble at violence; all fear death. Putting oneself in the place of another, one should not kill nor cause another to kill.

verses.pali: Sabbe tasanti daṇḍassa sabbesaṃ jīvitaṃ piyaṃ, attānaṃ upanamaṃ katvā na haneyya na ghātaye.
verses.english: All tremble at violence; life is dear to all. Putting oneself in the place of another, one should not kill nor cause another to kill.

verses.pali: Sukhakāmāni bhūtāni yo daṇḍena vihiṃsati, attano sukhamesāno pecca so na labhate sukhaṃ.
verses.english: One who, while himself seeking happiness, oppresses with violence other beings who also desire happiness, will not attain happiness hereafter.

verses.pali: Sukhakāmāni bhūtāni yo daṇḍena na hiṃsati, attano sukhamesāno pecca so labhate sukhaṃ.
verses.english: One who, while himself seeking happiness, does not oppress with violence other beings who also desire happiness, will find happiness hereafter.

verses.pali: Māvoca pharusaṃ kañci vuttā paṭivadeyyu taṃ, dukkhā hi sārambhakathā paṭidaṇḍā phuseyyu taṃ.
verses.english: Speak not harshly to anyone, for those spoken to might retort. Indeed, angry speech hurts, and retaliation may overtake you.

verses.pali: Sace neresi attānaṃ kaṃso upahato yathā, esa pattosi nibbānaṃ sārambho te na vijjati.
verses.english: If you make yourself as still as a broken gong does not vibrate, then you have attained Nibbāna; anger is not found in you.

verses.pali: Yathā daṇḍena gopālo gāvo pāceti gocaraṃ, evaṃ jarā ca maccu ca āyuṃ pācenti pāṇinaṃ.
verses.english: Just as a cowherd with his staff drives cows to the pasture, so do old age and death drive the life force of beings (from existence to existence).

verses.pali: Atha pāpāni kammāni karaṃ bālo na bujjhati, sehi kammehi dummedho aggidaḍḍho va tappati.
verses.english: When the fool commits evil deeds, he does not realize (their evil nature). The witless man is tormented by his own deeds, like one burnt by fire.

verses.pali: Yo daṇḍena adaṇḍesu appaduṭṭhesu dussati, dasannamaññataraṃ ṭhānaṃ khippameva nigacchati.
verses.english: He who inflicts violence on those who are unarmed, and offends those who are inoffensive, will soon come upon one of these ten states:

verses.pali: Vedanaṃ pharusaṃ jāniṃ sarīrassa ca bhedanaṃ, garukaṃ vāpi ābādhaṃ cittakkhepañ ca pāpuṇe.
verses.english: Sharp pain, or disaster, bodily injury, serious illness, or derangement of mind,

verses.pali: Rājato vā upassaggaṃ abbhakkhānaṃ va dāruṇaṃ, parikkhayaṃ vā ñātīnaṃ bhogānaṃ vā pabhaṅguraṃ.
verses.english: trouble from the government, or grave charges, loss of relatives, or loss of wealth,

verses.pali: Atha vāssa agārāni aggi ḍahati pāvako, kāyassa bhedā duppañño nirayaṃ sopapajjati.
verses.english: or else his houses are destroyed by ravaging fire; upon dissolution of the body that ignorant man is born in hell.

verses.pali: Na naggacariyā na jaṭā na paṅkā nānāsakā thaṇḍilasāyikā vā, rajojallaṃ ukkuṭikappadhānaṃ sodhenti maccaṃ avitiṇṇakaṅkhaṃ.
verses.english: Neither going about naked, nor matted locks, nor filth, nor fasting, nor lying on the ground, nor smearing oneself with ashes and dust, nor sitting on the heels (in penance) can purify a mortal who has not overcome doubt.

verses.pali: Alaṅkato cepi samaṃ careyya santo danto niyato brahmacārī, sabbesu bhūtesu nidhāya daṇḍaṃ so brāhmaṇo so samaṇo sa bhikkhu.
verses.english: Even though he be well-attired, yet if he is posed, calm, controlled and established in the holy life, having set aside violence towards all beings—he, truly, is a holy man, a renunciate, a monk.

verses.pali: Hirīnisedho puriso koci lokasmiṃ vijjati, yo niddaṃ apabodheti asso bhadro kasāmiva.
verses.english: Is there in this world any man restrained by modesty, who avoids reproach, as a thoroughbred horse avoids the whip?

verses.pali: Asso yathā bhadro kasāniviṭṭho ātāpino saṃvegino bhavātha, saddhāya sīlena ca vīriyena ca samādhinā dhammavinicchayena ca, sampannavijjācaraṇā patissatā jahissatha dukkhamidaṃ anappakaṃ.
verses.english: Like a thoroughbred horse touched by the whip, be strenuous, be filled with spiritual urgency. By faith and moral purity, by effort and meditation, by investigation of the truth, by being rich in knowledge and virtue, and by being mindful, destroy this unlimited suffering.

verses.pali: Udakaṃ hi nayanti nettikā usukārā namayanti tejanaṃ, dāruṃ namayanti tacchakā attānaṃ damayanti subbatā.
verses.english: Irrigators channel waters; fletchers straighten arrows; carpenters bend wood; the virtuous master themselves.

verses.pali: Ko nu hāso kim ānando niccaṃ pajjalite sati, andhakārena onaddhā padīpaṃ na gavessatha.
verses.english: Why is there laughter, why merriment, when this world is always burning? When you are shrouded in darkness, will you not seek a lamp?

verses.pali: Passa cittakataṃ bimbaṃ arukāyaṃ samussitaṃ, āturaṃ bahusaṅkappaṃ yassa natthi dhuvaṃ ṭhiti.
verses.english: Look upon this beautiful body, a mass of sores, joined together, diseased, and full of many thoughts, in which nothing lasts or is stable!

verses.pali: Parijiṇṇam idaṃ rūpaṃ roganīḷaṃ pabhaṅguraṃ, bhijjati pūtisandeho maraṇantañ hi jīvitaṃ.
verses.english: Thoroughly worn out is this body, a nest of disease, and fragile. This foul mass breaks up, for death is the end of life.

verses.pali: Yānimāni palāpāni disisvāna saradāni ca, kāpotakāni aṭṭhīni tāni disvāna kā rati.
verses.english: These dove-colored bones are like gourds that lie scattered about in autumn. Having seen them, how can one seek delight?

verses.pali: Aṭṭhīnaṃ nagaraṃ kataṃ maṃsalohitalepaṃ, yattha jarā ca maccu ca māno makkho ca ohito.
verses.english: This city (body) is built of bones, plastered with flesh and blood; within are decay and death, pride and jealousy.

verses.pali: Jīranti ve rājarathā sucittā, atho sarīram pi jaraṃ upeti, satañ ca dhammo na jaraṃ upeti, santo have sabbhi pavedayanti.
verses.english: Even gorgeous royal chariots wear out, and indeed this body too wears out. But the Dhamma of the good does not age; thus the good make it known to the good.

verses.pali: Appassutāyaṃ puriso balivaddo va jīrati, maṃsāni tassa vaḍḍhanti paññā tassa na vaḍḍhati.
verses.english: The man of little learning grows old like a bull. His muscles develop but his wisdom does not grow.

verses.pali: Anekajātisaṃsāraṃ sandhāvissaṃ anibbisaṃ, gahakārakaṃ gavesanto dukkhā jāti punappunaṃ.
verses.english: Through many a birth in saṃsāra have I wandered in vain, seeking the builder of this house (of life). Repeated birth is indeed suffering!

verses.pali: Gahakāraka diṭṭho'si puna gehaṃ na kāhasi, sabbā te phāsukā bhaggā gahakūṭaṃ visaṅkhataṃ, visaṅkhāragataṃ cittaṃ taṇhānaṃ khayam ajjhagā.
verses.english: O house-builder, you are seen! You will not build this house again. For your rafters are broken and your ridgepole shattered. My mind has reached the Unconditioned; I have attained the destruction of craving.

verses.pali: Acaritvā brahmacariyaṃ aladdhā yobbane dhanaṃ, jiṇṇakoñcā va jhāyanti khīṇamaccheva pallale.
verses.english: Those who in youth have not led the holy life, or have failed to acquire wealth, languish like old cranes in the pond that is without fish.

verses.pali: Acaritvā brahmacariyaṃ aladdhā yobbane dhanaṃ, senti cāpātikhīṇā va purāṇāni anutthunaṃ.
verses.english: Those who in youth have not led the holy life, or have failed to acquire wealth, lie sighing over the past, like worn out arrows shot from a bow.

verses.pali: Attānañ ce piyaṃ jaññā rakkheyya naṃ surakkhitaṃ, tiṇṇam aññataraṃ yāmaṃ paṭijaggeyya paṇḍito.
verses.english: If one holds oneself dear, one should diligently watch oneself. Let the wise man keep vigil during any one of the three watches of the night.

verses.pali: Attānam eva paṭhamaṃ patirūpe nivesaye, ath'aññam anusāseyya na kilisseyya paṇḍito.
verses.english: One should first establish oneself in what is proper; then only should one instruct another. Thus the wise man will not be reproached.

verses.pali: Attānaṃ ce tathā kayirā yathāññam anusāsati, sudanto vata dametha attā hi kira duddamo.
verses.english: If one would so conduct oneself as one instructs others, then, being fully controlled, one might indeed control others. One's own self is indeed difficult to control.

verses.pali: Attā hi attano nātho ko hi nātho paro siyā, attanā va sudantena nāthaṃ labhati dullabhaṃ.
verses.english: One truly is the protector of oneself; who else could the protector be? With oneself fully controlled, one gains a mastery that is hard to gain.

verses.pali: Attanā va kataṃ pāpaṃ attanā saṃkilissati, attanā akataṃ pāpaṃ attanāva visujjhati, suddhī asuddhi paccattaṃ nāñño aññaṃ visodhaye.
verses.english: By oneself is evil done; by oneself is one defiled. By oneself is evil left undone; by oneself is one made pure. Purity and impurity depended on oneself; no one can purify another.

verses.pali: Attadatthaṃ paratthena na hāpaye mahagghena, attadattham abhiññāya sadatthapasuto siyā.
verses.english: Let one not neglect one's own welfare for the sake of another, however great. Clearly understanding one's own welfare, let one be intent upon the good.

verses.pali: Na hi verena verāni sammantīdha kudācanaṃ, averena ca sammanti esa dhammo sanantano.
verses.english: Do not speak harshly to anyone; those who are spoken to will answer thee in the same way. Angry speech is painful, blows for blows will touch thee.

verses.pali: Sace neresi attānaṃ kaṃso upahato yathā, esa pattosi nibbānaṃ sārambho te na vijjati.
verses.english: If, like a shattered metal plate (gong), thou utter not, then thou hast reached Nibbāna; conflict is not found in thee.

verses.pali: Yathā daṇḍena gopālo gāvo pāceti gocaraṃ, evaṃ jarā ca maccu ca āyuṃ pācenti pāṇinaṃ.
verses.english: As a cowherd with his staff drives his cows into the stable, so do Age and Death drive the life of men.

verses.pali: Atha pāpāni kammāni karaṃ bālo na bujjhati, sehi kammehi dummedho aggidaḍḍho va tappati.
verses.english: A fool does not know when he commits his evil deeds: but the wicked man burns by his own deeds, as if burnt by fire.

verses.pali: Hīnaṃ dhammaṃ na seveyya pamādena na saṃvase, micchādiṭṭhiṃ na seveyya na siyā lokavaḍḍhano.
verses.english: Do not follow evil law. Do not live in thoughtlessness. Do not follow false ideas. Be not a friend of the world.

verses.pali: Uttiṭṭhe nappamajjeyya dhammaṃ sucaritaṃ care, dhammacārī sukhaṃ seti asmiṃ loke paramhi ca.
verses.english: Arise! Do not be thoughtless! Follow the law of virtue! The righteous rests in bliss in this world and in the next.

verses.pali: Dhammaṃ care sucaritaṃ na naṃ duccaritaṃ care, dhammacārī sukhaṃ seti asmiṃ loke paramhi ca.
verses.english: Follow the law of virtue; do not follow that of sin. The righteous rests in bliss in this world and in the next.

verses.pali: Yathā bubbulakaṃ passe yathā passe marīcikaṃ, evaṃ lokaṃ avekkhantaṃ maccurājā na passati.
verses.english: Look upon the world as a bubble, look upon it as a mirage. One who looks upon the world in this way, the king of death does not see.

verses.pali: Etha passathimaṃ lokaṃ cittaṃ rājarathūpamaṃ, yattha bālā visīdanti natthi saṅgo vijānataṃ.
verses.english: Come, look at this world, glittering like a royal chariot; the foolish are immersed in it, but the wise do not touch it.

verses.pali: Yo ca pubbe pamajjitvā pacchā so nappamajjati, so imaṃ lokaṃ pabhāseti abbhā muttova candimā.
verses.english: He who formerly was reckless and afterwards became sober brightens up this world like the moon when freed from clouds.

verses.pali: Yassa pāpaṃ kataṃ kammaṃ kusalena pidhīyati, so imaṃ lokaṃ pabhāseti abbhā muttova candimā.
verses.english: He whose evil deeds are covered by good deeds brightens up this world like the moon when freed from clouds.

verses.pali: Andhabhūto ayaṃ loko tanukettha vipassati, sakuṇo jālamuttova appo saggāya gacchati.
verses.english: This world is dark, few only can see here; a few only go to heaven, like birds escaped from the net.

verses.pali: Haṃsādiccapathe yanti ākāse yanti iddhiyā, nīyanti dhīrā lokamhā jetvā Māraṃ savāhiniṃ.
verses.english: The swans go on the path of the sun; they go through the ether by means of their miraculous power; the wise are led out of this world when they have conquered Māra and his train.

verses.pali: Ekaṃ dhammaṃ atītassa musāvādissa jantuno, vitiṇṇaparalokassa natthi pāpaṃ akāriyaṃ.
verses.english: If a man has transgressed one law, and speaks lies, and scoffs at another world, there is no evil he will not do.

verses.pali: Na ve kadariyā devalokaṃ vajanti bālā have nappasaṃsanti dānaṃ, dhīro ca dānaṃ anumodamāno teneva so hoti sukhī parattha.
verses.english: The uncharitable do not go to the world of the gods; fools only do not praise liberality; a wise man rejoices in liberality, and through it becomes blessed in the other world.

verses.pali: Paṭhavyā ekarajjena saggassa gamanena vā, sabbalokādhipaccena sotāpattiphalaṃ varaṃ.
verses.english: Better than sovereignty over the earth, better than going to heaven, better than lordship over all worlds is the reward of the first step in holiness.

verses.pali: Yassa jitaṃ nāvajīyati jitaṃ yassa no yāti koci loke, taṃ buddham anantagocaraṃ apadaṃ kena padena nessatha.
verses.english: He whose conquest is not conquered again, into whose conquest no one in this world enters, by what track can you lead him, the Awakened, the Omniscient, the trackless?

verses.pali: Yassa jālinī visattikā taṇhā natthi kuhiñci netave, taṃ buddham anantagocaraṃ apadaṃ kena padena nessatha.
verses.english: He whom no craving with its snares and poisons can lead astray, by what track can you lead him, the Awakened, the Omniscient, the trackless?

verses.pali: Ye jhānāpasutā dhīrā nekkhammūpasame ratā, devāpi tesaṃ pihayanti sambuddhānaṃ satīmataṃ.
verses.english: Even the gods hold dear the wise ones who are devoted to meditation, who delight in the repose of retirement (from the world), and who are mindful and perfectly enlightened.

verses.pali: Kiccho manussapaṭilābho kicchaṃ maccāna jīvitaṃ, kicchaṃ saddhammasavanaṃ kiccho buddhānam uppādo.
verses.english: Difficult is it to be born a man; difficult is the life of mortals. Difficult is it to gain access to the true law; difficult is the appearance of the Buddhas.

verses.pali: Sabbapāpassa akaraṇaṃ kusalassa upasampadā, sacittapariyodapanaṃ etaṃ buddhāna sāsanaṃ.
verses.english: To avoid all evil, to cultivate good, and to cleanse one's mind—this is the teaching of the Buddhas.

verses.pali: Khantī paramaṃ tapo titikkhā nibbānaṃ paramaṃ vadanti buddhā, na hi pabbajito parūpaghātī na samaṇo hoti paraṃ viheṭhayanto.
verses.english: The Buddhas say patience is the supreme penance, long-suffering the supreme Nibbāna; for he is not an anchorite (pabbajita) who strikes others, he is not an ascetic (samaṇa) who insults others.

verses.pali: Anūpavādo anūpaghāto pātimokkhe ca saṃvaro, mattaññutā ca bhattasmiṃ pantañ ca sayanāsanaṃ, adhicitte ca āyogo etaṃ buddhāna sāsanaṃ.
verses.english: Not to blame, not to strike, to live restrained under the law, to be moderate in eating, to sleep and sit alone, and to dwell on the highest thoughts—this is the teaching of the Buddhas.

verses.pali: Na kahāpaṇavassena titti kāmesu vijjati, appassādā dukhā kāmā iti viññāya paṇḍito.
verses.english: There is no satisfying sensual desires, even with the rain of gold coins. For sensual pleasures give little satisfaction and much pain. Having understood this, the wise man

verses.pali: Api dibbesu kāmesu ratiṃ so nādhigacchati, taṇhakkhayarato hoti sammāsambuddhasāvako.
verses.english: finds no delight even in heavenly pleasures. The disciple who is fully awakened delights only in the destruction of all desires.

verses.pali: Bahuṃ ve saraṇaṃ yanti pabbatāni vanāni ca, ārāmarukkhacetyāni manussā bhayatajjitā.
verses.english: Men, driven by fear, go to many a refuge, to mountains and forests, to groves and sacred trees.

verses.pali: Netaṃ kho saraṇaṃ khemaṃ netaṃ saraṇamuttamaṃ, netaṃ saraṇam āgamma sabbadukkhā pamuccati.
verses.english: But that is not a safe refuge, that is not the best refuge; a man is not delivered from all pains after having gone to that refuge.

verses.pali: Yo ca buddhañ ca dhammañ ca saṅghañ ca saraṇaṃ gato, cattāri ariyasaccāni sammappaññāya passati.
verses.english: He who takes refuge with Buddha, the Law, and the Church; he who, with clear understanding, sees the four holy truths:

verses.pali: Dukkhaṃ dukkhasamuppādaṃ dukkhassa ca atikkamaṃ, ariyaṃ caṭṭhaṅgikaṃ maggaṃ dukkhūpasamagāminaṃ.
verses.english: viz. pain, the origin of pain, the destruction of pain, and the eightfold holy way that leads to the quieting of pain;

verses.pali: Etaṃ kho saraṇaṃ khemaṃ etaṃ saraṇamuttamaṃ, etaṃ saraṇam āgamma sabbadukkhā pamuccati.
verses.english: that is the safe refuge, that is the best refuge; having gone to that refuge, a man is delivered from all pain.

verses.pali: Dullabho purisājañño na so sabbattha jāyati, yattha so jāyati dhīro taṃ kulaṃ sukhitaṃ hoti.
verses.english: A supernatural person (a Buddha) is not easily found, he is not born everywhere. Wherever such a sage is born, that race prospers.

verses.pali: Sukho buddhānam uppādo sukhā saddhammadesanā, sukhā saṅghassa sāmaggi samaggānaṃ tapo sukho.
verses.english: Happy is the arising of the awakened, happy is the teaching of the true law, happy is peace in the church, happy is the devotion of those who are at peace.

verses.pali: Pūjārahe pūjayato buddhe yadi va sāvake, papañcasamatikkante te munayo anāsave.
verses.english: He who pays homage to those who deserve homage, whether the awakened (Buddha) or their disciples, those who have overcome the host (of evils), and crossed the flood of sorrow,

verses.pali: Te tādise pūjayato nibbute akutobhaye, na sakkā puññaṃ saṅkhātuṃ imettam api kenaci.
verses.english: he who pays homage to such as have found deliverance and know no fear, his merit can never be measured by anybody.

verses.pali: Susukhaṃ vata jīvāma verinesu averino, verinesu manussesu viharāma averino.
verses.english: Very happily we live, friendly amidst the hostile. Amidst hostile men we dwell free from hatred.

verses.pali: Susukhaṃ vata jīvāma āturesu anāturā, āturesu manussesu viharāma anāturā.
verses.english: Very happily we live, free from ailments amidst the ailing. Amidst ailing men we dwell free from ailments.

verses.pali: Susukhaṃ vata jīvāma ussūkesu anussukā, ussūkesu manussesu viharāma anussukā.
verses.english: Very happily we live, free from avarice amidst the avaricious. Amidst avaricious men we dwell free from avarice.

verses.pali: Susukhaṃ vata jīvāma yesaṃ no natthi kiñcanaṃ, pītibhakkhā bhavissāma devā ābhassarā yathā.
verses.english: Very happily we live, we who possess nothing. Feeders on joy we shall be, like the radiant gods.

verses.pali: Jayaṃ veraṃ pasavati dukkhaṃ seti parājito, upasanto sukhaṃ seti hitvā jayaparājayaṃ.
verses.english: Victory breeds hatred, for the conquered is unhappy. He who has given up both victory and defeat, he, the contented, is happy.

verses.pali: Natthi rāgasamo aggi natthi dosasamo kali, natthi khandhāsamā dukkhā natthi santiparaṃ sukhaṃ.
verses.english: There is no fire like passion, there is no shark like hatred, there is no snare like folly, there is no torrent like greed.

verses.pali: Sudassaṃ vajjam aññesaṃ attano pana duddasaṃ, paresaṃ hi so vajjāni opunāti yathā bhusaṃ, attano pana chādeti kaliṃ va kitavā saṭho.
verses.english: The fault of others is easily perceived, but that of oneself is difficult to perceive; a man winnows his neighbor's faults like chaff, but his own fault he hides, as a cheat hides the bad die from the gambler.

verses.pali: Paravajjānupassissa niccaṃ ujjhānasaññino, āsavā tassa vaḍḍhanti ārā so āsavakkhayā.
verses.english: If a man looks after the faults of others, and is always inclined to be offended, his own passions will grow, and he is far from the destruction of passions.

verses.pali: Ākāse padaṃ natthi samaṇo natthi bāhire, papañcābhiratā pajā nippapañcā tathāgatā.
verses.english: There is no path through the air, a man is not a monk by outward observances. The world delights in vanity, the Tathāgatas (the Buddhas) are free from vanity.

verses.pali: Ākāse padaṃ natthi samaṇo natthi bāhire, saṅkhārā sassatā natthi natthi buddhānaṃ iñjitaṃ.
verses.english: There is no path through the air, a man is not a monk by outward observances. No creatures are eternal; but the awakened (Buddha) are never shaken.

verses.pali: Na tena thero so hoti yenassa palitaṃ siro, paripakko vayo tassa moghajiṇṇo ti vuccati.
verses.english: A man is not an elder because his head is grey; his age may be ripe, but he is called 'Old-in-vain.'

verses.pali: Yamhi saccañ ca dhammo ca ahiṃsā saṃyamo damo, sa ve vantamalo dhīro thero iti vuccati.
verses.english: He in whom there is truth, virtue, love, restraint, moderation, he who is free from impurity and is wise, he is called an elder.

verses.pali: Ayoge yuñjamattānaṃ yogasmiñ ca ayojayaṃ, atthaṃ hitvā piyaggāhī pihetattānuyoginaṃ.
verses.english: Apply yourself to what should not be done; do not apply yourself to what should be done. The slothful who cling to the pleasant miss the goal, while others reach it.

verses.pali: Piyato jāyatī soko piyato jāyatī bhayaṃ, piyato vippamuttassa natthi soko kuto bhayaṃ.
verses.english: From attachment springs grief, from attachment springs fear. For one who is wholly free from attachment there is no grief, and whence can fear come?

verses.pali: Pemato jāyatī soko pemato jāyatī bhayaṃ, pemato vippamuttassa natthi soko kuto bhayaṃ.
verses.english: From affection springs grief, from affection springs fear. For one who is wholly free from affection there is no grief, and whence can fear come?

verses.pali: Ratiyā jāyatī soko ratiyā jāyatī bhayaṃ, ratiyā vippamuttassa natthi soko kuto bhayaṃ.
verses.english: From pleasure springs grief, from pleasure springs fear. For one who is wholly free from pleasure there is no grief, and whence can fear come?

verses.pali: Kāmato jāyatī soko kāmato jāyatī bhayaṃ, kāmato vippamuttassa natthi soko kuto bhayaṃ.
verses.english: From lust springs grief, from lust springs fear. For one who is wholly free from lust there is no grief, and whence can fear come?

verses.pali: Taṇhāya jāyatī soko taṇhāya jāyatī bhayaṃ, taṇhāya vippamuttassa natthi soko kuto bhayaṃ.
verses.english: From craving springs grief, from craving springs fear. For one who is wholly free from craving there is no grief, and whence can fear come?

verses.pali: Sīladassanasampannaṃ dhammaṭṭhaṃ saccavedinaṃ, attano kamma kubbānaṃ taṃ jano kurute piyaṃ.
verses.english: People hold dear one who is endowed with virtue and insight, who is principled, has realized the truth, and who himself does what he ought to be doing.

verses.pali: Chandajāto anakkhāte manasā ca phuṭo siyā, kāmesu ca appaṭibaddhacitto uddhaṃsoto ti vuccati.
verses.english: One who has developed a wish for the Undeclared (Nibbāna), who is filled with longing, and whose mind is not bound by material pleasures, is called 'bound upstream.'

verses.pali: Cirappavāsiṃ purisaṃ dūrato sotthim āgataṃ, ñātimittā suhajjā ca abhinandanti āgataṃ.
verses.english: When, after a long absence, a man returns safely from afar, his kinsmen, friends, and well-wishers welcome him back.

verses.pali: Tatheva katapuññam pi asmā lokā paraṃ gataṃ, puññāni paṭigaṇhanti piyaṃ ñātim iv āgataṃ.
verses.english: In the same way, when a man who has done good deeds goes from this world to the next, his good deeds receive him there, as kinsmen welcome a dear one on his return.

verses.pali: Mātaraṃ pitaraṃ hantvā rājāno dve ca khattiyo, raṭṭhaṃ sānucaraṃ hantvā anīgho yāti brāhmaṇo.
verses.english: Having slain mother (craving), father (conceit), two warrior-kings (eternalism and nihilism), and destroyed a country (sense-objects) together with its treasurer (attachment), ungrieving goes the holy man.

verses.pali: Mātaraṃ pitaraṃ hantvā rājāno dve ca sotthiyo, veyagghapañcamaṃ hantvā anīgho yāti brāhmaṇo.
verses.english: Having slain mother, father, two learned kings, and a tiger as the fifth (the five hindrances), ungrieving goes the holy man.

verses.pali: Kodhaṃ jahe vippajaheyya mānaṃ, sabbaṃ saṃyojanaṃ samatikkameyya; taṃ nāmarūpasmiṃ asajjamānaṃ akiñcanaṃ nānupatanti dukkhā.
verses.english: Give up anger, renounce pride, overcome all fetters. When one is not attached to name and form and owns nothing, no sufferings befall him.

verses.pali: Yo ve uppatitaṃ kodhaṃ rathaṃ bhantaṃ va vāraye, taṃ ahaṃ sārathiṃ brūmi rasmiggāho itaro jano.
verses.english: He who holds back arisen anger like a rolling chariot, him I call a real driver; other people are but holding the reins.

verses.pali: Akkodhena jine kodhaṃ asādhuṃ sādhunā jine, jine kadariyaṃ dānena saccenālikavādinaṃ.
verses.english: Overcome anger with non-anger; overcome evil with good; overcome the miser with generosity; overcome the liar with truth.

verses.pali: Saccaṃ bhaṇe na kujjheyya dajjā appam pi yācito, etehi tīhi ṭhānehi gacche devāna santike.
verses.english: Speak the truth, do not yield to anger; give, if thou art asked for little; by these three steps thou wilt go near the gods.

verses.pali: Ahiṃsakā ye munayo niccaṃ kāyena saṃvutā, te yanti accutaṃ ṭhānaṃ yattha gantvā na socare.
verses.english: The sages who injure none, who always control their body, they go to the unchangeable place (Nibbāna), where, if they have gone, they grieve no more.

verses.pali: Sadā jāgaramānānaṃ ahorattānusikkhinaṃ, nibbānaṃ adhimuttānaṃ atthaṃ gacchanti āsavā.
verses.english: Those who are ever watchful, who study day and night, and who strive after Nibbāna, their passions will come to an end.

verses.pali: Purāṇam etaṃ Atula na etaṃ ajjatanāmiva, nindanti tuṇhim āsīnaṃ nindanti bahubhāṇinaṃ, mitabhāṇim pi nindanti natthi loke anindito.
verses.english: This is an old saying, O Atula, this is not only of today: 'They blame him who sits silent, they blame him who speaks much, they also blame him who says little; there is no one on earth who is not blamed.'

verses.pali: Na cāhu na ca bhavissati na cetarahi vijjati, ekantaṃ nindito poso ekantaṃ vā pasaṃsito.
verses.english: There never was, there never will be, nor is there now, a person who is always blamed, or a person who is always praised.

verses.pali: Yaṃ ce viññū pasaṃsanti anuvicca suve suve, acchiddavuttiṃ medhāviṃ paññāsīlasamāhitaṃ.
verses.english: But he whom the wise praise, after observing him day after day, is one whose conduct is blameless, who is intelligent, and who is endowed with knowledge and virtue.

verses.pali: Nikkhaṃ jambonadasseva ko taṃ ninditumarahati, devāpi naṃ pasaṃsanti brahmunāpi pasaṃsito.
verses.english: Who dares to blame him who is like a coin made of gold from the Jambū river? Even the gods praise him, and by Brahmā too he is praised.

verses.pali: Kāyappakopam rakkheyya kāyena saṃvuto siyā, kāyaduccaritaṃ hitvā kāyena sucaritaṃ care.
verses.english: Beware of bodily anger, and control thy body! Leave the sins of the body, and with thy body practise virtue!

verses.pali: Vacīpakopam rakkheyya vācāya saṃvuto siyā, vacīduccaritaṃ hitvā vācāya sucaritaṃ care.
verses.english: Beware of the anger of the tongue, and control thy tongue! Leave the sins of the tongue, and practise virtue with thy tongue!

verses.pali: Manopakopam rakkheyya manasā saṃvuto siyā, manoduccaritaṃ hitvā manasā sucaritaṃ care.
verses.english: Beware of the anger of the mind, and control thy mind! Leave the sins of the mind, and practise virtue with thy mind!

verses.pali: Kāyena saṃvutā dhīrā atho vācāya saṃvutā, manasā saṃvutā dhīrā te ve suparisaṃvutā.
verses.english: The wise who control their body, who control their tongue, the wise who control their mind, are indeed well controlled.

verses.pali: Paṇḍupalāso va dāni'si yamapurisāpi ca taṃ upaṭṭhitā, uyyogamukhe ca tiṭṭhasi na ca gantubhayaṃ tava atthi.
verses.english: You are now like a withered leaf, and even death's messengers await you. You stand at departure's threshold, but you have no provisions for the journey.

verses.pali: So karohi dīpam attano khippaṃ vāyama paṇḍito, niddhantamalo anaṅgaṇo dibbaṃ ariyabhūmiṃ ehisi.
verses.english: Make an island for yourself! Strive quickly; be wise! Purged of stain and flawless, you will reach the noble land of the gods.

verses.pali: Upanītavayo ca dāni'si sampayāto'si yamassa santike, vāso'pi ca te natthi antarā ca te natthi gantubhayaṃ.
verses.english: Your life has come to an end now; you are setting forth into the presence of Yama, the king of death, and there is no resting place for you on the way, nor have you any provisions for the journey.

verses.pali: So karohi dīpam attano khippaṃ vāyama paṇḍito, niddhantamalo anaṅgaṇo na punaṃ jātijaraṃ upehisi.
verses.english: Make an island for yourself! Strive quickly; be wise! Purged of stain and flawless, you will not come again to birth and decay.

verses.pali: Anupubbena medhāvī thokaṃ thokaṃ khaṇe khaṇe, kammāro rajatasseva niddhame malamattano.
verses.english: Little by little, bit by bit, moment by moment, a wise man should remove his own impurities, as a smith removes his dross from silver.

verses.pali: Ayasā va malaṃ samuṭṭhitaṃ tatuṭṭhāya tameva khādati, evaṃ atidhonacārinaṃ sāni kammāni nayanti duggatim.
verses.english: As rust arising from iron eats away the very iron from which it arose, even so do their own deeds lead transgressors to states of woe.

verses.pali: Asajjhāyamalā mantā anuṭṭhānamalā gharā, malaṃ vaṇṇassa kosajjaṃ pamādo rakkhato malaṃ.
verses.english: Non-recitation is the rust of mantras; non-exertion is the rust of homes; sloth is the rust of beauty; carelessness is the rust of a guard.

verses.pali: Malitthiyā duccaritaṃ maccheriyaṃ dadato malaṃ, malā ve pāpakā dhammā asmiṃ loke paramhi ca.
verses.english: Misconduct is the rust of a woman; stinginess is the rust of a giver; evil deeds are rust in this world and the next.

verses.pali: Tato malā malataraṃ avijjā paramaṃ malaṃ, etaṃ malaṃ pahatvāna nimmalā hotha bhikkhavo.
verses.english: But there is a rust worse than all these rusts—ignorance is the greatest rust. O monks! Cast away this rust and be free from stain!

verses.pali: Sujīvaṃ ahirikena kākasūrena dhaṃsinā, pakkhandinā pagabbhena saṃkiliṭṭhena jīvitaṃ.
verses.english: Life is easy to live for a man who is without shame, a crow hero, a mischief-maker, an insulting, bold, and wretched fellow.

verses.pali: Hirīmatā ca dujjīvaṃ niccaṃ sucigavesinā, alīnenāppagabbhena suddhājīvena passatā.
verses.english: But life is hard to live for a modest man, who always seeks for what is pure, who is disinterested, quiet, spotless, and intelligent.

verses.pali: Yo pāṇam atipāteti musāvādañ ca bhāsati, loke adinnaṃ ādiyati paradāraṃ ca gacchati.
verses.english: He who destroys life, utters lies, takes what is not given to him, goes to another man's wife,

verses.pali: Surāmerayapānañ ca yo naro anuyuñjati, idh'eva m'eso lokasmiṃ mūlaṃ khaṇati attano.
verses.english: and the man who gives himself to drinking intoxicating liquors, he, even in this world, digs up his own root.

verses.pali: Evaṃ bho purisa jānāhi pāpadhammā asaññatā, mā taṃ lobho adhammo ca ciraṃ dukkhāya randhayuṃ.
verses.english: O man, know this, that the unrestrained are in a bad state; take care that greediness and vice do not bring thee to grief for a long time!

verses.pali: Dadāti ve yathāsaddhaṃ yathāpasādanaṃ jano, tattha yo maṅku bhavati paresaṃ pānabhojane, na so divā vā rattiṃ vā samādhim adhigacchati.
verses.english: The world gives according to their faith or according to their pleasure: if a man frets about the food and the drink given to others, he will not attain concentration, either by day or by night.

verses.pali: Yassa c'etaṃ samucchinnaṃ mūlaghaccaṃ samūhataṃ, sa ve divā vā rattiṃ vā samādhim adhigacchati.
verses.english: He in whom that feeling is destroyed, and taken out with the very root, finds rest by day or by night.

verses.pali: Natthi rāgasamo aggi natthi dosasamo gaho, natthi mohasamaṃ jālaṃ natthi taṇhāsamā nadī.
verses.english: There is no fire like passion, there is no losing throw like hatred, there is no pain like this body, there is no happiness higher than rest.

verses.pali: Jighacchāparamā rogā saṅkhāraparamā dukhā, etaṃ ñatvā yathābhūtaṃ nibbānaṃ paramaṃ sukhaṃ.
verses.english: Hunger is the worst of diseases, the body the greatest of pains; if one knows this truly, that is Nibbāna, the highest happiness.

verses.pali: Ārogyaparamā lābhā santuṭṭhiparamaṃ dhanaṃ, vissāsaparamā ñāti nibbānaṃ paramaṃ sukhaṃ.
verses.english: Health is the greatest of gifts, contentedness the best riches; trust is the best of relationships, Nibbāna the highest happiness.

verses.pali: Pavivekarasaṃ pitvā rasaṃ upasamassa ca, niddaro hoti nippāpo dhammapītirasaṃ pibaṃ.
verses.english: He who has tasted the sweetness of solitude and tranquillity, is free from fear and free from sin, while he tastes the sweetness of drinking in the law.

verses.pali: Sāhu dassanam ariyānaṃ sannivāso sadā sukho, adassanena bālānaṃ niccameva sukhī siyā.
verses.english: The sight of the noble is good, to live with them is always happiness; if a man does not see fools, he will be truly happy.

verses.pali: Na tena hoti dhammaṭṭho yenatthaṃ sāhasā naye, yo ca atthaṃ anatthañ ca ubho niccheyya paṇḍito.
verses.english: A man is not just if he carries a matter by violence; no, he who distinguishes both right and wrong, who is learned and leads others, not by violence, but by law and equity, and who is guarded by the law and intelligent, he is called just.

verses.pali: Asāhasena dhammena samena nayatī pare, dhammassa gutto medhāvī dhammaṭṭho ti pavuccati.
verses.english: A man is not learned because he talks much; he who is patient, free from hatred and fear, he is called learned.

verses.pali: Na tāvatā thero hoti yāvatā jiṇṇasīso ca, paripakko vayo tassa moghajiṇṇo ti vuccati.
verses.english: A man is not an elder because his head is grey; his age may be ripe, but he is called 'Old-in-vain.'

verses.pali: Yamhi saccañ ca dhammo ca ahiṃsā saṃyamo damo, sa ve vantamalo dhīro thero iti vuccati.
verses.english: He in whom there is truth, virtue, love, restraint, moderation, he who is free from impurity and is wise, he is called an elder.

verses.pali: Na vākkaraṇamattena vaṇṇapokkharatāya vā, sādhurūpo naro hoti issukī maccharī saho.
verses.english: An envious greedy, dishonest man does not become respectable by means of much talking only, or by the beauty of his complexion.

verses.pali: Yassa c'etaṃ samucchinnaṃ mūlaghaccaṃ samūhataṃ, sa vantadoso medhāvī sādhurūpo ti vuccati.
verses.english: He in whom all this is destroyed, and taken out with the very root, he, when freed from hatred and wise, is called respectable.

verses.pali: Na muṇḍakena samaṇo abbato alikavatā, icchālobhasamāpanno samaṇo kiṃ bhavissati.
verses.english: Not by tonsure does an undisciplined man who speaks falsehood become a monk. Whoever is possessed by desire and greediness, how can he be a monk?

verses.pali: Yo ca sameti pāpāni aṇuṃ thūlāni sabbaso, samitattā hi pāpānaṃ samaṇo ti pavuccati.
verses.english: He who always quiets the evil, whether small or large, because of a monk's quieting of the evil he is called a monk (samaṇa).

verses.pali: Na tena bhikkhu so hoti yāvatā bhikkhate pare, vissaṃ dhammaṃ samādāya bhikkhu hoti na tāvatā.
verses.english: A man is not a mendicant (bhikkhu) simply because he asks others for alms; he who adopts the whole law is a bhikkhu, not he who only begs.

verses.pali: Yodha puññañ ca pāpañ ca bāhetvā brahmacariyavā, saṅkhāya loke carati sa ve bhikkhūti vuccati.
verses.english: He who is above good and evil, who is chaste, who with knowledge passes through the world, he indeed is called a bhikkhu.

verses.pali: Na monena munī hoti mūḷharūpo aviddasu, yo ca tulaṃ va paggayha varamādāya paṇḍito.
verses.english: A man does not become a muni by observing silence (mona), if he be foolish and ignorant; but the wise man who, taking the balance, chooses the good and avoids evil, he is a muni, and is a muni thereby; he who in this world weighs both sides is called a muni.

verses.pali: Pāpāni parivajjeti sa munī teneva so munī, yo munāti ubho loke muni teneva pavuccati.
verses.english: A man is not a muni because he observes silence; he who is wise and good is a muni.

verses.pali: Na tena ariyo hoti yena pāṇāni hiṃsati, ahiṃsā sabbapāṇānaṃ ariyo ti pavuccati.
verses.english: A man is not an elect (ariya) because he injures living creatures; because he has pity on all living creatures, therefore is a man called ariya (elect).

verses.pali: Na sīlabbatamattena bāhusaccena vā pana, atha vā samādhilābhena vivittasayanena vā.
verses.english: Not only by discipline and vows, not only by much learning, not by entering into a trance, not by sleeping alone, do I earn the happiness of release which no worldling can know. Bhikkhu, be not confident as long as thou hast not attained the extinction of desires.

verses.pali: Phusāmi nekkhammasukhaṃ aputhujjanasevitaṃ, bhikkhu vissāsam āpādi appatto āsavakkhayaṃ.
verses.english: Not only by discipline and vows, not only by much learning, not by entering into a trance, not by sleeping alone, do I earn the happiness of release which no worldling can know. Bhikkhu, be not confident as long as thou hast not attained the extinction of desires.

verses.pali: Uddhaṃ tiriyaṃ apācīnaṃ yāni kānici dhammā, te sabbe anicca dukkha anattā ti ñatvā, na kiñci maññe ti na ca maññamāno, viharāmi suddho vimalo anāsavo.
verses.english: Whatever things exist above, below, around, and between, knowing them all to be impermanent, painful, and without a self, thinking 'I am nothing,' and not thinking so, I live pure, stainless, and without defilements.

verses.pali: Sīlabbatena suddhi vā ñāṇena vā tapena vā, samādhilābhena vā pana, vivittasayanena vā, phusāmi nekkhammasukhaṃ aputhujjanasevitaṃ, bhikkhu vissāsam āpādi appatto āsavakkhayaṃ ti.
verses.english: Not by discipline and vows alone, nor by knowledge, nor by austerities, nor by meditation, nor by sleeping alone, do I experience the bliss of renunciation not enjoyed by ordinary people. O monk, do not be overconfident until you have reached the destruction of all defilements.

verses.pali: Maggānaṭṭhaṅgiko seṭṭho saccānaṃ caturo padā, virāgo seṭṭho dhammānaṃ dvipadānaṃ ca cakkhumā.
verses.english: The best of paths is the eightfold path; the best of truths are the four noble truths; the best of virtues is passionlessness; the best of men is the one who sees.

verses.pali: Eso va maggo natthañño dassanassa visuddhiyā, etaṃ hi tumhe paṭipajjatha mārassetaṃ pamohanaṃ.
verses.english: This is the path, there is no other that leads to the purifying of intelligence. Go on this path! Everything else is the deceit of Māra (the tempter).

verses.pali: Etaṃ hi tumhe paṭipannā dukkhassantaṃ karissatha, akkhāto vo mayā maggo aññāya sallakantanaṃ.
verses.english: If you go on this path, you will make an end of pain! The path was preached by me, when I had understood the removal of the thorns (in the flesh).

verses.pali: Tumhehi kiccam ātappaṃ akkhātāro tathāgatā, paṭipannā pamokkhanti jhāyino mārabandhanā.
verses.english: You yourself must make an effort. The Tathāgatas (Buddhas) are only preachers. The thoughtful who enter the way are freed from the bondage of Māra.

verses.pali: "Sabbe saṅkhārā aniccā" ti yadā paññāya passati, atha nibbindati dukkhe esa maggo visuddhiyā.
verses.english: "All created things perish," he who knows and sees this becomes passive in pain; this is the way of purification.

verses.pali: "Sabbe saṅkhārā dukkhā" ti yadā paññāya passati, atha nibbindati dukkhe esa maggo visuddhiyā.
verses.english: "All created things are grief and pain," he who knows and sees this becomes passive in pain; this is the way of purification.

verses.pali: "Sabbe dhammā anattā" ti yadā paññāya passati, atha nibbindati dukkhe esa maggo visuddhiyā.
verses.english: "All forms of existence are unreal," he who knows and sees this becomes passive in pain; this is the way of purification.

verses.pali: Uṭṭhānakālamhi anuṭṭhahāno yuvā balī ālasiyaṃ upagato, saṃsannasaṅkappamano kusīto paññāya maggaṃ na vindati.
verses.english: He who does not rouse himself when it is time to rise, who, though young and strong, is full of sloth, whose will and thought are weak, that lazy and idle man will never find the way to knowledge.

verses.pali: Vācānurakkhī manasā susaṃvuto kāyena ca akusalaṃ na kayirā, ete tayo kammapathe visodhaye ārādhaye maggam isippaveditaṃ.
verses.english: Watching his speech, well restrained in mind, let a man never commit any wrong with his body! Let a man but keep these three roads of action clear, and he will achieve the way which is taught by the wise.

verses.pali: Yogā ve jāyatī bhūri ayogā bhūrisaṅkhayo, etaṃ dvedhāpathaṃ ñatvā bhavāya vibhavāya ca, tathāttānaṃ niveseyya yathā bhūri pavaḍḍhati.
verses.english: Through zeal knowledge is gotten, through lack of zeal knowledge is lost; let a man who knows this double path of gain and loss thus place himself that knowledge may grow.

verses.pali: Vanaṃ chindatha mā rukkhaṃ vanato jāyate bhayaṃ, chetvā vanañ ca vanathañ ca nibbanā hotha bhikkhavo.
verses.english: Cut down the whole forest (of lust), not a tree only! Danger comes out of the forest (of lust). When you have cut down both the forest (of lust) and its undergrowth, then, Bhikkhus, you will be rid of the forest and free!

verses.pali: Yāva hi vanatho na chijjati aṇumatto'pi narassa nārisu, paṭibaddhamano va tāva so vaccho khīrapakova mātari.
verses.english: So long as the love of man towards women, even the smallest, is not destroyed, so long is his mind in bondage, as the calf that drinks milk is to its mother.

verses.pali: Ucchinda sineham attano kumudaṃ sāradikaṃ va pāṇinā, santimaggam eva brūhaya nibbānaṃ sugatena desitaṃ.
verses.english: Cut out the love of self, like an autumn lotus, with thy hand! Cherish the road of peace. Nibbāna has been shown by Sugata (Buddha).

verses.pali: Idha vassaṃ vasissāmi idha hemantagimhisu, iti bālo vicinteti antarāyaṃ na bujjhati.
verses.english: "Here I shall dwell in the rain, here in winter and summer," thus the fool meditates, and does not think of his death.

verses.pali: Taṃ puttapasusammattaṃ byāsattamanasaṃ naraṃ, suttaṃ gāmaṃ mahogho va maccu ādāya gacchati.
verses.english: Death comes and carries off that man, praised for his children and flocks, his mind distracted, as a flood carries off a sleeping village.

verses.pali: Na santi puttā tāṇāya na pitā nāpi bandhavā, antakenādhipannassa natthi ñātīsu tāṇatā.
verses.english: Sons are no help, nor a father, nor relations; there is no help from kinsfolk for one whom death has seized.

verses.pali: Etam atthavasaṃ ñatvā paṇḍito sīlasamvuto, nibbānagamanaṃ maggaṃ khippameva visodhaye.
verses.english: A wise and good man who knows the meaning of this, should quickly clear the way that leads to Nibbāna.

verses.pali: Mattāsukhapariccāgā passe ce vipulaṃ sukhaṃ, caje mattāsukhaṃ dhīro sampassaṃ vipulaṃ sukhaṃ.
verses.english: If by giving up a lesser happiness one may behold a greater happiness, let the wise man give up the lesser happiness in consideration of the greater happiness.

verses.pali: Paradukkhūpadhānena attano sukhamicchati, verasaṃsaggasaṃsaṭṭho verā so na parimuccati.
verses.english: He who seeks his own happiness by inflicting pain on others, being entangled by the bonds of hatred, is never freed from hatred.

verses.pali: Yaṃ hi kiccaṃ tadapaviddhaṃ akiccaṃ pana kayirati, unnaḷānaṃ pamattānaṃ tesaṃ vaḍḍhanti āsavā.
verses.english: What should be done is neglected, what should not be done is done. In those who are heedless and arrogant, the taints increase.

verses.pali: Yesañca susamāraddhā niccaṃ kāyagatā sati, akiccaṃ te na sevanti kicce sātaccakārino, satānaṃ sampajānānaṃ atthaṃ gacchanti āsavā.
verses.english: But those who are always mindful of the body, who do not follow what should not be done, who steadfastly do what should be done, of those mindful and clearly comprehending ones, the taints come to an end.

verses.pali: Mātaraṃ pitaraṃ hantvā rājāno dve ca khattiye, raṭṭhaṃ sānucaraṃ hantvā anīgho yāti brāhmaṇo.
verses.english: Having slain mother and father and two warrior kings, having destroyed the kingdom with its subjects, the brahmin goes untroubled.
