verses.pali: Mātaraṃ pitaraṃ hantvā rājāno dve ca sotthiye, veyagghapañcamaṃ hantvā anīgho yāti brāhmaṇo.
verses.english: Having slain mother and father and two brahmin kings, having slain the tiger as the fifth, the brahmin goes untroubled.

verses.pali: Suppabuddhaṃ pabujjhanti sadā gotamasāvakā, yesaṃ divā ca ratto ca niccaṃ buddhagatā sati.
verses.english: Well awakened the disciples of Gotama ever arise - they who by day and night are always mindful of the Buddha.

verses.pali: Suppabuddhaṃ pabujjhanti sadā gotamasāvakā, yesaṃ divā ca ratto ca niccaṃ dhammagatā sati.
verses.english: Well awakened the disciples of Gotama ever arise - they who by day and night are always mindful of the Dhamma.

verses.pali: Suppabuddhaṃ pabujjhanti sadā gotamasāvakā, yesaṃ divā ca ratto ca niccaṃ saṅghagatā sati.
verses.english: Well awakened the disciples of Gotama ever arise - they who by day and night are always mindful of the Sangha.

verses.pali: Suppabuddhaṃ pabujjhanti sadā gotamasāvakā, yesaṃ divā ca ratto ca niccaṃ kāyagatā sati.
verses.english: Well awakened the disciples of Gotama ever arise - they who by day and night are always mindful of the body.

verses.pali: Suppabuddhaṃ pabujjhanti sadā gotamasāvakā, yesaṃ divā ca ratto ca ahiṃsāya rato mano.
verses.english: Well awakened the disciples of Gotama ever arise - they who by day and night delight in non-violence.

verses.pali: Suppabuddhaṃ pabujjhanti sadā gotamasāvakā, yesaṃ divā ca ratto ca bhāvanāya rato mano.
verses.english: Well awakened the disciples of Gotama ever arise - they who by day and night delight in meditation.

verses.pali: Duppabbajjaṃ durabhiramaṃ durāvāsā gharā dukhā, dukkhosamānasaṃvāso dukkhānupatitaddhagū, tasmā na caddhagū siyā na ca dukkhānupatito siyā.
verses.english: Difficult is the life of renunciation, difficult to enjoy; difficult also is the household life, painful when one is with uncongenial people. The traveler in samsara is ever subject to pain. Therefore, be not a traveler in samsara; be not the one to be repeatedly subjected to pain.

verses.pali: Saddho sīlena sampanno yasobhogasamappito, yaṃ yaṃ padesaṃ bhajati tattha tattheva pūjito.
verses.english: He who is full of faith and virtue, possessed of fame and wealth, is honored wherever he goes.

verses.pali: Dūre santo pakāsenti himavanto va pabbato, asantettha na dissanti rattiṃ khittā yathā sarā.
verses.english: The good shine from afar like the Himalayan peaks. The bad are not seen here, like arrows shot in the night.

verses.pali: Ekāsanaṃ ekaseyyaṃ eko caramatandito, eko damayamattānaṃ vanante ramito siyā.
verses.english: Sitting alone, lying down alone, walking alone without being lazy, one who alone subdues himself would find delight in the forest.

verses.pali: Abhūtavādī nirayaṃ upeti yo vāpi katvā na karomiccāha, ubho pi te pecca samā bhavanti nihīnakammā manujā parattha.
verses.english: He who speaks untruth goes to hell, as does he who having done (a wrong) says 'I did not do it.' Both, being men of base actions, become equal (in their fate) in the other world.

verses.pali: Kāsāvakaṇṭhā bahavo pāpadhammā asaññatā, pāpā pāpehi kammehi nirayaṃ te upapajjare.
verses.english: Many with yellow robes around their necks are of bad character and unrestrained. Being wicked, by wicked deeds they are reborn in hell.

verses.pali: Seyyo ayoguḷo bhutto tatto aggisikhūpamo, yañce bhuñjeyya dussīlo raṭṭhapiṇḍaṃ asaññato.
verses.english: Better it is to swallow a red-hot iron ball, burning like a flame, than for an immoral and unrestrained person to eat the alms of the country.

verses.pali: Cattāri ṭhānāni naro pamatto āpajjati paradārūpasevī, apuññalābhaṃ na nikāmaseyyaṃ nindaṃ tatīyaṃ nirayaṃ catutthaṃ.
verses.english: Four misfortunes befall a heedless man who commits adultery: acquisition of demerit, disturbed sleep, blame as the third, and hell as the fourth.

verses.pali: Apuññalābho ca gatī ca pāpikā bhītassa bhītāya ratī ca thokikā, rājā ca daṇḍaṃ garukaṃ paṇeti, tasmā naro paradāraṃ na seve.
verses.english: There is acquisition of demerit as well as evil destiny. Brief is the joy of the frightened man and woman. The king imposes a heavy punishment. Therefore, let no man consort with another's wife.

verses.pali: Kuso yathā duggahito hatthamevānukantati, sāmaññaṃ dupparāmaṭṭhaṃ nirayāyupakaḍḍhati.
verses.english: Just as kusa grass, wrongly grasped, cuts the hand, so does the monastic life wrongly lived drag one to hell.

verses.pali: Yaṃ kiñci sithilaṃ kammaṃ saṃkiliṭṭhañca yaṃ vataṃ, saṅkassaraṃ brahmacariyaṃ na taṃ hoti mahapphalaṃ.
verses.english: Whatever deed that is slack, whatever observance that is corrupt, suspicious celibate life - none of these bear much fruit.

verses.pali: Kayirā ce kayirāthenaṃ daḷhamenaṃ parakkame, sithilo hi paribbājo bhiyyo ākirate rajaṃ.
verses.english: If anything is to be done, let one do it with sustained vigor. A lax monastic life stirs up the dust (of passions) all the more.

verses.pali: Akataṃ dukkaṭaṃ seyyo pacchā tapati dukkaṭaṃ, katañca sukataṃ seyyo yaṃ katvā nānutappati.
verses.english: An evil deed is better left undone: a misdeed torments one later on. But a good deed is better done, doing which one does not grieve.

verses.pali: Nagaraṃ yathā paccantaṃ guttaṃ santarabāhiraṃ, evaṃ gopetha attānaṃ khaṇo vo mā upaccagā, khaṇātītā hi socanti nirayamhi samappitā.
verses.english: Like a border city guarded within and without, so guard yourself. Do not let the moment pass you by. Those who let the moment pass grieve when they are consigned to hell.

verses.pali: Alajjitāye lajjanti lajjitāye na lajjare, micchādiṭṭhisamādānā sattā gacchanti duggatiṃ.
verses.english: Those who are ashamed of what they should not be ashamed of, and are not ashamed of what they should be ashamed of - such beings, embracing wrong views, go to the woeful state.

verses.pali: Abhaye bhayadassino bhaye cābhayadassino, micchādiṭṭhisamādānā sattā gacchanti duggatiṃ.
verses.english: Those who see fear in what is not to be feared, and see no fear in the fearsome - such beings, embracing wrong views, go to the woeful state.

verses.pali: Avajje vajjamatino vajje cāvajjadassino, micchādiṭṭhisamādānā sattā gacchanti duggatiṃ.
verses.english: Those who see fault in the faultless, and see no fault in the faulty - such beings, embracing wrong views, go to the woeful state.

verses.pali: Vajjañca vajjato ñatvā avajjañca avajjato, sammādiṭṭhisamādānā sattā gacchanti suggatiṃ.
verses.english: Those who know the faulty as faulty, and the faultless as faultless - such beings, embracing right views, go to the blissful state.

verses.pali: Ahaṃ nāgova saṅgāme cāpato patitaṃ saraṃ, ativākyaṃ titikkhissaṃ dussīlo hi bahujjano.
verses.english: Like an elephant in battle withstands the arrows shot from a bow, so will I endure abuse; verily, most people are ill-natured.

verses.pali: Dantaṃ nayanti samitiṃ dantaṃ rājābhirūhati, danto seṭṭho manussesu yotivākyaṃ titikkhati.
verses.english: The tamed (elephant) is led into a crowd; the king mounts the tamed (elephant). Best among men is the subdued one who endures abuse.

verses.pali: Varamassatarā dantā ājānīyā ca sindhavā, kuñjarā ca mahānāgā attadanto tato varaṃ.
verses.english: Good are trained mules, good are trained thoroughbred horses, good are trained great elephants. But better still is the one who has trained himself.

verses.pali: Na hi etehi yānehi gaccheyya agataṃ disaṃ, yathāttanā sudantena danto dantena gacchati.
verses.english: Surely never by these vehicles would one go to the untrodden land (Nibbana), as does one who is controlled through his well-controlled, tamed self.

verses.pali: Dhanapālako nāma kuñjaro kaṭukabhedano dunnivārayo, baddho kabaḷaṃ na bhuñjati sumarati nāgavanassa so.
verses.english: The elephant called Dhanapala, in rut and uncontrollable, does not eat a morsel when bound. He yearns for the elephant forest.

verses.pali: Middhī yadā hoti mahagghaso ca niddāyitā samparivattasāyī, mahāvarāhova nivāpapuṭṭho punappunaṃ gabbhamupeti mando.
verses.english: When one is sluggish and gluttonous, sleeping and rolling around in bed like a fat pig fed in the sty, such a fool is reborn again and again.

verses.pali: Idaṃ pure cittamacāri cārikaṃ yenicchakaṃ yatthakāmaṃ yathāsukhaṃ, tadajjahaṃ niggahessāmi yoniso hatthippabhinnaṃ viya aṅkusaggaho.
verses.english: Formerly this mind wandered as it liked, where it wished and according to its pleasure. Now I shall control it thoroughly, as a mahout controls an elephant in rut with a goad.

verses.pali: Appamādaratā hotha sacittamanurakkhatha, duggā uddharathattānaṃ paṅke sannova kuñjaro.
verses.english: Delight in heedfulness! Guard your mind well! Draw yourself out of the evil way as an elephant draws itself out of the mud.

verses.pali: Sace labhetha nipakaṃ sahāyaṃ saddhiṃ caraṃ sādhu vihāri dhīraṃ, abhibhuyya sabbāni parissayāni careyya tenattamano satīmā.
verses.english: If you find a wise companion, a fellow traveler leading a good life and acting wisely, you should travel with him joyfully and mindfully, overcoming all dangers.

verses.pali: No ce labhetha nipakaṃ sahāyaṃ saddhiṃ caraṃ sādhu vihāri dhīraṃ, rājāva raṭṭhaṃ vijitaṃ pahāya eko care mātaṅgaraññe va nāgo.
verses.english: If you do not find a wise companion, a fellow traveler leading a good life and acting wisely, then like a king who leaves his conquered kingdom, travel alone like an elephant in the elephant forest.

verses.pali: Ekassa caritaṃ seyyo natthi bāle sahāyatā, eko care na ca pāpāni kayirā appossukko mātaṅgaraññe va nāgo.
verses.english: Better it is to travel alone; there is no fellowship with a fool. Let one travel alone and commit no sin, with few wishes like an elephant in the elephant forest.

verses.pali: Atthamhi jātamhi sukhā sahāyā tuṭṭhī sukhā yā itarītarena, puññaṃ sukhaṃ jīvitasaṅkhayamhi pāpassa parivajaanaṃ sukhaṃ.
verses.english: Pleasant are friends when need arises; pleasant is satisfaction with whatever (one has); pleasant is merit when life is at an end; pleasant is the shunning of all evil.

verses.pali: Sukhā matteyyatā loke atho petteyyatā sukhā, sukhā sāmaññatā loke atho brahmññatā sukhā.
verses.english: Pleasant in this world is reverence to mother; pleasant too is reverence to father; pleasant is reverence to ascetics; pleasant too is reverence to the noble ones.

verses.pali: Sukhaṃ yāva jarā sīlaṃ sukhā saddhā patiṭṭhitā, sukho paññāya paṭilābho pāpānaṃ akaraṇaṃ sukhaṃ.
verses.english: Pleasant is virtue until old age; pleasant is steadfast faith; pleasant is the acquisition of wisdom; pleasant is the non-commission of evil.

verses.pali: Manujassa pamattacārino taṇhā vaḍḍhati māluvā viya, so plavatī hurāhuraṃ phalamicchaṃva vanasmi vānaro.
verses.english: The craving of the heedless man grows like a creeper. He jumps from life to life like a monkey seeking fruit in the forest.

verses.pali: Yaṃ esā sahate jammī taṇhā loke visattikā, sokā tassa pavaḍḍhanti abhivaṭṭhaṃva bīraṇaṃ.
verses.english: Whoever is overcome by this wretched, clinging craving, his sorrows grow like grass after rain.

verses.pali: Yo cetaṃ sahate jammiṃ taṇhaṃ loke duraccayaṃ, sokā tamhā papatanti udabinduva pokkharā.
verses.english: But whoever overcomes this wretched craving, so difficult to overcome, sorrows fall away from him like water drops from a lotus leaf.

verses.pali: Taṃ vo vadāmi bhaddaṃ vo yāvantettha samāgatā, taṇhāya mūlaṃ khaṇatha usīratthova bīraṇaṃ, mā vo naḷaṃva sotova māro bhañji punappunaṃ.
verses.english: This I say to you: Good luck to you all who have assembled here! Dig up the root of craving like one who digs up birana grass for its fragrant root. Do not let Mara crush you again and again as a flood crushes a reed.

verses.pali: Yathāpi mūle anupaddave daḷhe chinnopi rukkho punareva rūhati, evampi taṇhānusaye anūhate nibbattatī dukkhamidaṃ punappunaṃ.
verses.english: Just as a tree with roots unharmed and firm, though hewn down, sprouts again, even so while latent craving is not rooted out, this suffering arises again and again.

verses.pali: Yassa chattiṃsati sotā manāpasavanā bhusā, vāhā vahanti duddiṭṭhiṃ saṅkappā rāganissitā.
verses.english: The man in whom the thirty-six streams (of craving) that flow towards pleasurable objects are strong, is swept away by the current of his thoughts which are based on passion.

verses.pali: Savanti sabbadhi sotā latā ubbhijja tiṭṭhati, tañca disvā lataṃ jātaṃ mūlaṃ paññāya chindatha.
verses.english: Streams (of craving) flow everywhere; the creeper sprouts and stands. Seeing the creeper that has sprung up, cut off the root with wisdom.

verses.pali: Saritāni sinehitāni ca somanassāni bhavanti jantuno, te sātasitā sukhesino te ve jātijarūpagā.
verses.english: Flowing and soaked with craving are the joys of beings. Bent on pleasure and seeking happiness, such men fall prey to birth and decay.

verses.pali: Tasiṇāya purakkhatā pajā parisappanti sasova bandhito, saṃyojanasaṅgasattā dukkhamupenti punappunaṃ cirāya.
verses.english: Beset by craving, people run about like an ensnared hare. Held fast by mental fetters and bonds, they undergo suffering again and again, for long.

verses.pali: Tasiṇāya purakkhatā pajā parisappanti sasova bandhito, tasmā tasiṇaṃ vinodaye bhikkhu ākaṅkhī virāgamattano.
verses.english: Beset by craving, people run about like an ensnared hare. Therefore, let the monk who desires his own freedom from passion, shake off craving.

verses.pali: Yo vanādhimutto vanamutto vanameva dhāvati, taṃ puggalametha passatha mutto bandhanaṃeva dhāvati.
verses.english: He who having left the forest (of household life) gives himself over to the forest (of the senses), and having been freed from the forest runs back to the forest (of desire), come, behold that man! Though freed, he runs back to bondage.

verses.pali: Na taṃ daḷhaṃ bandhanamāhu dhīrā yadāyasaṃ dārujapabbajañca, sārattarattā maṇikuṇḍalesu puttesu dāresu ca yā apekhā.
verses.english: That is not a strong fetter, say the wise, which is made of iron, wood or hemp. But the infatuation and longing for jewels and ornaments, children and wives - that the wise say is a far stronger fetter.

verses.pali: Etaṃ daḷhaṃ bandhanamāhu dhīrā ohārinaṃ sithilaṃ duppamuñcaṃ, etampi chetvāna paribbajanti anapekkhino kāmasukhaṃ pahāya.
verses.english: That fetter the wise call strong, which drags down, is supple, and hard to loosen. Having cut even this, they wander forth, free from longing and abandoning sensual pleasures.

verses.pali: Ye rāgarattānupatanti sotaṃ sayaṃkataṃ makkaṭakova jālaṃ, etampi chetvāna vajanti dhīrā anapekkhino sabbadukkhaṃ pahāya.
verses.english: Those who are infatuated with lust fall back into the stream as does a spider into the web spun by itself. Having cut even this, the wise wander forth, free from longing, abandoning all suffering.

verses.pali: Muñca pure muñca pacchato majjhe muñca bhavassa pāragū, sabbattha vimuttamānaso na punaṃ jātijaraṃ upehisi.
verses.english: Let go of the past, let go of the future, let go of the present. Having crossed to the farther shore of existence, with mind released from all, you will not again undergo birth and decay.

verses.pali: Vitakkamathitassa jantuno tibbarāgassa subhānupassino, bhiyyo taṇhā pavaḍḍhati esa kho daḷhaṃ karoti bandhanaṃ.
verses.english: For the person who is disturbed by thoughts, who has strong passions, who sees only the beautiful, craving increases more and more. Such a one makes the fetter strong.

verses.pali: Vitakkasamathaṃ rato asubhaṃ bhāvayatī sadā, sato esa vyantikāhiti esa checchati mārabandhaṃ.
verses.english: But he who delights in subduing thoughts, who meditates on the impurities, who is ever mindful - it is he who will make an end of craving and rend asunder Mara's fetter.

verses.pali: Niṭṭhaṅgato asantāsī vītataṇho anaṅgaṇo, acchindi bhavasallāni antimoyaṃ samussayo.
verses.english: He who has reached the goal, who is fearless, who is without craving, who is passionless, has broken the thorns of existence. This is his last body.

verses.pali: Vītataṇho anādāno niruttipadakovido, akkharānaṃ sannipātaṃ jaññā pubbāparāni ca, sa ve antimasārīro mahāpurisoti vuccati.
verses.english: He who is without craving and grasping, who is skilled in etymology and knows the meaning of words, who knows the order of letters - he is called the great man, bearer of his final body.

verses.pali: Sabbābhibhū sabbavidūhamasmi sabbesu dhammesu anūpalitto, sabbañjaho taṇhākkhaye vimutto sayaṃ abhiññāya kamuddiseyyaṃ.
verses.english: I have conquered all, I know all, I am unattached to all things, I have renounced all, I am freed through the destruction of craving. Having realized this by myself, whom shall I call my teacher?

verses.pali: Sabbadānaṃ dhammadānaṃ jināti sabbarasaṃ dhammaraso jināti, sabbaratiṃ dhammarati jināti taṇhākkhayo sabbadukkhaṃ jināti.
verses.english: The gift of Dhamma surpasses all gifts; the taste of Dhamma surpasses all tastes; the joy in Dhamma surpasses all joys. The destruction of craving conquers all suffering.

verses.pali: Hananti bhogā dummedhaṃ no ca pāragavesino, bhogataṇhāya dummedho hanti aññeva attanaṃ.
verses.english: Riches destroy the foolish, but not those who seek the beyond. Through craving for riches the foolish one destroys himself as (if he were destroying) others.

verses.pali: Tiṇadosāni khettāni rāgadosā ayaṃ pajā, tasmā hi vītarāgesu dinnaṃ hoti mahapphalaṃ.
verses.english: Weeds are the bane of fields; lust is the bane of mankind. Therefore, offerings made to those free from lust yield abundant fruit.

verses.pali: Tiṇadosāni khettāni dosadosā ayaṃ pajā, tasmā hi vītadosesu dinnaṃ hoti mahapphalaṃ.
verses.english: Weeds are the bane of fields; hatred is the bane of mankind. Therefore, offerings made to those free from hatred yield abundant fruit.

verses.pali: Tiṇadosāni khettāni mohadosā ayaṃ pajā, tasmā hi vītamohesu dinnaṃ hoti mahapphalaṃ.
verses.english: Weeds are the bane of fields; delusion is the bane of mankind. Therefore, offerings made to those free from delusion yield abundant fruit.

verses.pali: Tiṇadosāni khettāni icchādosā ayaṃ pajā, tasmā hi vigaticchesu dinnaṃ hoti mahapphalaṃ.
verses.english: Weeds are the bane of fields; desire is the bane of mankind. Therefore, offerings made to those free from desire yield abundant fruit.

verses.pali: Cakkhunā saṃvaro sādhu sādhu sotena saṃvaro, ghānena saṃvaro sādhu sādhu jivhāya saṃvaro.
verses.english: Good is restraint in the eye; good is restraint in the ear; good is restraint in the nose; good is restraint in the tongue.

verses.pali: Kāyena saṃvaro sādhu sādhu vācāya saṃvaro, manasā saṃvaro sādhu sādhu sabbattha saṃvaro, sabbattha saṃvuto bhikkhu sabbadukkhā pamuccati.
verses.english: Good is restraint in the body; good is restraint in speech; good is restraint in the mind; restraint everywhere is good. The monk who is restrained everywhere is freed from all suffering.

verses.pali: Hattha-saññato pāda-saññato vācāya saññato saññatuttamo, ajjhattarato samāhito eko santusito tamāhu bhikkhun ti.
verses.english: He who is restrained in hand, restrained in foot, restrained in speech, and supremely restrained, who delights in inward calm, who is composed, solitary, and content - him they call a monk.

verses.pali: Yo mukhasaññato bhikkhu mantabhāṇī anuddhato, atthaṃ dhammañca dīpeti madhuraṃ tassa bhāsitaṃ.
verses.english: That monk who is controlled in tongue, who speaks wisely, who is not puffed up, who explains the meaning and the Dhamma - sweet is his speech.

verses.pali: Dhammārāmo dhammarato dhammaṃ anuvicintayaṃ, dhammaṃ anussaraṃ bhikkhu saddhammā na parihāyati.
verses.english: That monk who dwells in the Dhamma, who delights in the Dhamma, who meditates on the Dhamma, who well remembers the Dhamma, does not fall away from the true Dhamma.

verses.pali: Salābhaṃ nātimaññeyya nāññesaṃ pihayaṃ care, aññesaṃ pihayaṃ bhikkhu samādhiṃ nādhigacchati.
verses.english: Let him not despise what he has received, nor envy the gains of others. The monk who envies the gains of others does not attain concentration.

verses.pali: Appalābhopi ce bhikkhu salābhaṃ nātimaññati, taṃ ve devā pasaṃsanti suddhājīviṃ atanditaṃ.
verses.english: Even if a monk receives only a little, if he does not despise what he has received, the gods praise such a one who is pure in livelihood and is not lazy.

verses.pali: Sabbaso nāmarūpasmiṃ yassa natthi mamāyitaṃ, asatā ca na socati sa ve bhikkhūti vuccati.
verses.english: He who has no attachment whatsoever for name and form (mind and body), who does not grieve for that which is non-existent - he is truly called a monk.

verses.pali: Mettāvihārī yo bhikkhu pasanno buddhasāsane, adhigacche padaṃ santaṃ saṅkhārūpasamaṃ sukhaṃ.
verses.english: That monk who dwells in loving-kindness, who is pleased with the Buddha's teaching, attains the peaceful state, the bliss of the cessation of conditioned existence.

verses.pali: Siñca bhikkhu imaṃ nāvaṃ sittā te lahumessati, chetvā rāgañca dosañca tato nibbānamehisi.
verses.english: Empty this boat, O monk! Emptied, it will sail lightly. Having cut off lust and hatred, you will thereby reach Nibbana.

verses.pali: Pañca chinde pañca jahe pañca cuttari bhāvaye, pañca saṅgātigo bhikkhu oghatinnoti vuccati.
verses.english: Cut off the five, abandon the five, cultivate the five more. The monk who has overcome the five attachments is called 'One who has crossed the flood.'

verses.pali: Jhāya bhikkhu mā ca pramādo mā te kāmaguṇe bhamassu cittaṃ, mā lohaguḷaṃ gilī pamatto mā kandī dukkhamidanti ḍayhamāno.
verses.english: Meditate, O monk! Do not be heedless. Let not your mind whirl on sensual pleasures. Do not heedlessly swallow a red-hot iron ball, lest you cry 'Oh, the pain!' when burning.

verses.pali: Natthi jhānaṃ apaññassa paññā natthi ajhāyato, yamhi jhānañca paññā ca sa ve nibbānasantike.
verses.english: There is no concentration for one who lacks wisdom; there is no wisdom for one who lacks concentration. He in whom are both concentration and wisdom is close to Nibbana.

verses.pali: Suññāgāraṃ paviṭṭhassa santacittassa bhikkhuno, amānusī ratī hoti sammā dhammaṃ vipassato.
verses.english: The monk who has entered an empty house (i.e., whose mind is empty of the three poisons), whose mind is calm, who perceives the Dhamma clearly, experiences a joy that transcends all human joys.

verses.pali: Yato yato sammasati khandhānaṃ udayabbayaṃ, labhatī pītipāmojjaṃ amataṃ taṃ vijānatāṃ.
verses.english: Whenever he reflects on the rise and fall of the aggregates, he gains joy and happiness. That, for those who know, is the Deathless.

verses.pali: Tatrāyamādi bhavati idha paññassa bhikkhuno, indriyagutti santuṭṭhi pātimokkhe ca saṃvaro.
verses.english: This, then, is the beginning for a wise monk: guarding the senses, contentment, restraint according to the fundamental moral code.

verses.pali: Mitte bhajassu kalyāṇe suddhājīve atandite, paṭisanthāravutyassa ācārakusalo siyā, tato pāmojjabahulo dukkhassantaṃ karissati.
verses.english: Associate with good friends who are pure in livelihood and not lazy. Let one be skilled in conduct and courtesy, and as a result be full of joy and make an end to suffering.

verses.pali: Vassikā viya pupphāni maddavāni pamuñcati, evaṃ rāgañca dosañca vippamuñcetha bhikkhavo.
verses.english: Just as the jasmine sheds its withered flowers, so, O monks, should you shed lust and hatred.

verses.pali: Santakāyo santavāco santavā susamāhito, vantalokāmiso bhikkhu upasantoti vuccati.
verses.english: The monk who is calm in body, calm in speech, calm in mind, who is well-composed and has spewed out worldly things - he is truly called 'Peaceful.'

verses.pali: Attanā codayattānaṃ attamanuvitakkehi, so attagutto satimā sukhaṃ bhikkhu vihāhisi.
verses.english: By oneself one must censure oneself and scrutinize oneself. The monk who is self-guarded and mindful will live happily.

verses.pali: Attā hi attano nātho attā hi attano gati, tasmā saññamayattānaṃ assaṃ bhadraṃva vāṇijo.
verses.english: Self is the master of self, self is the refuge of self. Therefore, control yourself as a merchant controls a noble horse.

verses.pali: Pāmojjabahulo bhikkhu pasanno buddhasāsane, adhigacche padaṃ santaṃ saṅkhārūpasamaṃ sukhaṃ.
verses.english: The monk who is full of joy, who is pleased with the Buddha's teaching, attains the peaceful state, the bliss of the cessation of conditioned existence.

verses.pali: Yo have daharo bhikkhu yuñjati buddhasāsane, so imaṃ lokaṃ pabhāseti abbhā muttova candimā.
verses.english: That monk who, though young, applies himself to the Buddha's teaching, illuminates this world like the moon freed from clouds.

verses.pali: Chinda sotaṃ parakkamma kāme panuda brāhmaṇa, saṅkhārānaṃ khayaṃ ñatvā akataññūsi brāhmaṇa.
verses.english: Strive and cut the stream! Dispel sensual desires, O brahmin! Knowing the destruction of conditioned things, be a knower of the Uncreated, O brahmin!

verses.pali: Yadā dvayesu dhammeu pāragū hoti brāhmaṇo, athassa sabbe saṃyogā atthaṃ gacchanti jānato.
verses.english: When the brahmin has crossed beyond the two states (of tranquillity and insight), then all the fetters of that knowing one disappear.

verses.pali: Yassa pāraṃ apāraṃ vā pārāpāraṃ na vijjati, vītaddaraṃ visaṃyuttaṃ tamahaṃ brūmi brāhmaṇaṃ.
verses.english: For whom there exists neither the farther shore nor the nearer shore, nor both farther and nearer shores, who is free from distress and fetters - him I call a brahmin.

verses.pali: Jhāyiṃ virajamāsīnaṃ katakiccamanāsavaṃ, uttamatthamanuppattaṃ tamahaṃ brūmi brāhmaṇaṃ.
verses.english: He who is meditative, free from dust, settled, whose task is done, who is free from taints, who has attained the highest goal - him I call a brahmin.

verses.pali: Divā tapati ādicco rattiṃ ābhāti candimā, sannaddho khattiyo tapati jhāyī tapati brāhmaṇo, atha sabbamahorattiṃ buddho tapati tejasā.
verses.english: The sun shines by day, the moon by night. The warrior shines in armor, the brahmin shines in meditation. But all day and night the Buddha shines in glory.

verses.pali: Bāhitapāpoti brāhmaṇo samacariyā samaṇoti vuccati, pabbājayamattano malaṃ tasmā pabbajitoti vuccati.
verses.english: Because he has discarded evil, he is called a 'brahmin'; because he lives in peace, he is called a 'recluse'; because he has renounced his impurities, he is called a 'renunciant.'

verses.pali: Na brāhmaṇassa pahareyya nāssa muñcetha brāhmaṇo, dhī brāhmaṇassa hantāraṃ tato dhī yassa muñcati.
verses.english: One should not strike a brahmin, nor should a brahmin give way to anger. Shame on him who strikes a brahmin! More shame on him who gives way to anger!

verses.pali: Na brāhmaṇassetadakiñci seyyo yadā nisedho manaso piyehi, yato yato hiṃsamano nivattati tato tato sammati-meva dukkhaṃ.
verses.english: Nothing is better for a brahmin than when he restrains his mind from pleasant things. Whenever the intent to harm subsides, suffering is calmed.

verses.pali: Yassa kāyena vācāya manasā natthi dukkaṭaṃ, saṃvutaṃ tīhi ṭhānehi tamahaṃ brūmi brāhmaṇaṃ.
verses.english: He who does no evil in body, speech or mind, who is restrained in these three ways - him I call a brahmin.

verses.pali: Yamhā dhammaṃ vijāneyya sammāsambuddhadesitaṃ, sakkaccaṃ taṃ namasseyya aggihuttaṃva brāhmaṇo.
verses.english: From whomever one would learn the Dhamma taught by the Perfectly Enlightened Buddha, let him worship that teacher respectfully, as a brahmin worships the sacrificial fire.

verses.pali: Na jaṭāhi na gottena na jaccā hoti brāhmaṇo, yamhi saccañca dhammo ca so sucī so ca brāhmaṇo.
verses.english: Not by matted hair, nor by clan, nor by birth does one become a brahmin. He in whom truth and dhamma exist, he is pure, he is a brahmin.

verses.pali: Kiṃ te jaṭāhi dummedha kiṃ te ajinasāṭiyā, abbhantaraṃ te gahanaṃ bāhiraṃ parimajjasi.
verses.english: What is the use of your matted hair, O fool? What is the use of your deerskin garment? Within you is the tangle (of passions); you clean only the outside.

verses.pali: Paṃsukūladharaṃ jantuṃ kisaṃ dhamanisanthataṃ, ekaṃ vanasmiṃ jhāyantaṃ tamahaṃ brūmi brāhmaṇaṃ.
verses.english: The person who wears robes made of rags, who is lean, whose veins stand out, who meditates alone in the forest - him I call a brahmin.

verses.pali: Na cāhaṃ brāhmaṇaṃ brūmi yonijaṃ mattisambhavaṃ, bhovādī nāma so hoti sace hoti sakiñcano, akiñcanaṃ anādānaṃ tamahaṃ brūmi brāhmaṇaṃ.
verses.english: I do not call him a brahmin merely because he is born of a (brahmin) womb or sprung from a (brahmin) mother. He is merely a 'bho-sayer' if he has possessions. He who has nothing and takes nothing - him I call a brahmin.

verses.pali: Sabbasaṃyojanaṃ chetvā yo ve na paritassati, saṅgātigaṃ visaṃyuttaṃ tamahaṃ brūmi brāhmaṇaṃ.
verses.english: He who has cut all fetters and does not tremble, who has gone beyond bonds and is unattached - him I call a brahmin.

verses.pali: Chetvā naddhiṃ varattañca sandānaṃ sahanukkamaṃ, ukkhittapalighaṃ buddhaṃ tamahaṃ brūmi brāhmaṇaṃ.
verses.english: He who has cut the strap (hatred) and the thong (craving), and the rope (wrong views) together with the appendages (latent tendencies), who has lifted the crossbar (ignorance), who is enlightened - him I call a brahmin.

verses.pali: Akkosaṃ vadhabandhañca aduṭṭho yo titikkhati, khantībalaṃ balānīkaṃ tamahaṃ brūmi brāhmaṇaṃ.
verses.english: He who without anger endures abuse, beating and imprisonment, whose power is patience and whose army is fortitude - him I call a brahmin.

verses.pali: Akkodhanaṃ vatavantaṃ sīlavantaṃ anussadaṃ, dantaṃ antimasārīraṃ tamahaṃ brūmi brāhmaṇaṃ.
verses.english: He who is free from anger, who observes religious duties, who is virtuous, free from craving, who is subdued and bears his final body - him I call a brahmin.

verses.pali: Vāri pokkharapatteva āraggeriva sāsapo, yo na limpati kāmesu tamahaṃ brūmi brāhmaṇaṃ.
verses.english: Like water on a lotus leaf, like a mustard seed on the point of a needle, he who is not attached to sensual pleasures - him I call a brahmin.

verses.pali: Yo dukkhassa pajānāti idheva khayamattano, pannabhāraṃ visaṃyuttaṃ tamahaṃ brūmi brāhmaṇaṃ.
verses.english: He who realizes here in this life the end of his suffering, who has laid down the burden and is unattached - him I call a brahmin.

verses.pali: Gambhīrapaññaṃ medhāviṃ maggāmaggassa kovidaṃ, uttamatthamanuppattaṃ tamahaṃ brūmi brāhmaṇaṃ.
verses.english: He whose wisdom is deep, who is wise, who is skilled in the right and wrong path, who has attained the highest goal - him I call a brahmin.

verses.pali: Asaṃsaṭṭhaṃ gahaṭṭhehi anāgārehi cūbhayaṃ, anokasāriṃ appicchhaṃ tamahaṃ brūmi brāhmaṇaṃ.
verses.english: He who is not intimate with householders or with the homeless, who wanders without an abode, who is of few desires - him I call a brahmin.

verses.pali: Nidhāya daṇḍaṃ bhūtesu tasesu thāvaresu ca, yo na hanti na ghāteti tamahaṃ brūmi brāhmaṇaṃ.
verses.english: He who has laid down the rod with regard to beings, moving and unmoving, who neither harms nor kills - him I call a brahmin.

verses.pali: Aviruddhaṃ viruddhesu attadaṇḍesu nibbutaṃ, sādānesu anādānaṃ tamahaṃ brūmi brāhmaṇaṃ.
verses.english: He who is friendly among the hostile, peaceful among the violent, unattached among the attached - him I call a brahmin.

verses.pali: Yassa rāgo ca doso ca māno makkho ca pātito, sāsaporiva āraggā tamahaṃ brūmi brāhmaṇaṃ.
verses.english: He from whom lust, hatred, pride and hypocrisy have fallen away, like a mustard seed from the point of a needle - him I call a brahmin.

verses.pali: Akakkasaṃ viññāpaniṃ giraṃ saccamudāhare, yāya nābhisaje kañci tamahaṃ brūmi brāhmaṇaṃ.
verses.english: He who speaks gentle, instructive, truthful words, by which he offends no one - him I call a brahmin.

verses.pali: Yo'dha dīghaṃ va rassaṃ vā aṇuṃ thūlaṃ subhāsubhaṃ, loke adinnaṃ nādiyati tamahaṃ brūmi brāhmaṇaṃ.
verses.english: He who in this world takes nothing that is not given, be it long or short, small or large, fair or foul - him I call a brahmin.

verses.pali: Āsā yassa na vijjanti asmiṃ loke paramhi ca, nirāsāsaṃ visaṃyuttaṃ tamahaṃ brūmi brāhmaṇaṃ.
verses.english: He in whom there are no desires for this world or the next, who is free from desires and unattached - him I call a brahmin.

verses.pali: Yassālayā na vijjanti aññāya akathaṅkathī, amatogadhamanuppattaṃ tamahaṃ brūmi brāhmaṇaṃ.
verses.english: He who has no attachments, who through knowledge has no doubts, who has reached the depth of the Deathless - him I call a brahmin.

verses.pali: Yo'dha puññañca pāpañca ubho saṅgamupaccagā, asokaṃ virajaṃ suddhaṃ tamahaṃ brūmi brāhmaṇaṃ.
verses.english: He who has here transcended both good and evil attachments, who is sorrowless, stainless and pure - him I call a brahmin.

verses.pali: Candaṃva vimalaṃ suddhaṃ vippasannamanāvilaṃ, nandībhavaparikkhīṇaṃ tamahaṃ brūmi brāhmaṇaṃ.
verses.english: He who like the moon is spotless, pure, clear and unagitated, in whom delight in existence is extinct - him I call a brahmin.

verses.pali: Yo imaṃ palighaṃ duggaṃ saṃsāraṃ mohamaccagā, tiṇṇo pāragato jhāyī anejo akathaṅkathī, anupādāya nibbuto tamahaṃ brūmi brāhmaṇaṃ.
verses.english: He who has passed beyond this dangerous, difficult path of samsara and delusion, who has crossed over, reached the other shore, is meditative, free from craving, free from doubts, who clinging to nothing has attained Nibbana - him I call a brahmin.

verses.pali: Yo'dha kāme pahantvāna anāgāro paribbaje, kāmabhavaparikkhīṇaṃ tamahaṃ brūmi brāhmaṇaṃ.
verses.english: He who has here given up sensual desires and wanders forth as a homeless one, in whom sensual desire and existence are extinct - him I call a brahmin.

verses.pali: Yo'dha taṇhaṃ pahantvāna anāgāro paribbaje, taṇhābhavaparikkhīṇaṃ tamahaṃ brūmi brāhmaṇaṃ.
verses.english: He who has here given up craving and wanders forth as a homeless one, in whom craving and existence are extinct - him I call a brahmin.

verses.pali: Hitvā mānusakaṃ yogaṃ dibbaṃ yogaṃ upaccagā, sabbayogavisaṃyuttaṃ tamahaṃ brūmi brāhmaṇaṃ.
verses.english: He who has given up human bonds, transcended heavenly bonds, who is completely unbound - him I call a brahmin.

verses.pali: Hitvā ratiñca aratiñca sītibhūtaṃ nirūpadhiṃ, sabbalokābhibhuṃ vīraṃ tamahaṃ brūmi brāhmaṇaṃ.
verses.english: He who has given up pleasure and displeasure, who is cooled and free from substrates, the hero who has conquered all the worlds - him I call a brahmin.

verses.pali: Cutiṃ yo vedi sattānaṃ upapattiñca sabbaso, asattaṃ sugataṃ buddhaṃ tamahaṃ brūmi brāhmaṇaṃ.
verses.english: He who knows in every way the death and rebirth of beings, who is unattached, well-gone, awakened - him I call a brahmin.

verses.pali: Yassa gatiṃ na jānanti devā gandhabbamānusā, khīṇāsavaṃ arahantaṃ tamahaṃ brūmi brāhmaṇaṃ.
verses.english: He whose destination the gods, gandharvas and men do not know, who has destroyed the taints, who is an arahant - him I call a brahmin.

verses.pali: Yassa pure ca pacchā ca majjhe ca natthi kiñcanaṃ, akiñcanaṃ anādānaṃ tamahaṃ brūmi brāhmaṇaṃ.
verses.english: He who has nothing before, behind or in between, who possesses nothing and grasps nothing - him I call a brahmin.

verses.pali: Usabhaṃ pavaraṃ vīraṃ mahesiṃ vijitāvinaṃ, anejaṃ nhātakaṃ buddhaṃ tamahaṃ brūmi brāhmaṇaṃ.
verses.english: He who is a bull among men, noble, heroic, a great sage, a conqueror, free from craving, cleansed, awakened - him I call a brahmin.

verses.pali: Pubbenivāsaṃ yo vedi saggāpāyañca passati, atho jātikkhayaṃ patto abhiññāvosito muni, sabbavositavosānaṃ tamahaṃ brūmi brāhmaṇaṃ.
verses.english: He who knows his former lives, who sees heaven and hell, who has reached the end of births, who has perfected supernormal knowledge, the sage who has completed all that is to be completed - him I call a brahmin.
